When people ask me what piece of kit I have in my kitchen that I love and would recommend, there are a few contenders. Firstly, every home cook just needs to start with a good knife, a wooden spoon, a chopping board and a heavy pan. Beyond this, I rely heavily on my mixer, food processor and my pressure cooker.

I use Chinese salted fermented black beans which are a cupboard essential for me. You can get these in any Chinese food store, usually in small plastic bags or a yellow cardboard tub. Fermented foods are a way of borrowing time from before and adding fast flavour. How lovely is that? I soaked the beans briefly and then simply blitzed all of the ingredients together, then cooked it for 10 minutes. Done!

Tarama means salted and cured cod roe, that being the egg sack of the fish. It is luscious and richÂ and is used to great effect in many food cultures, notably Japanese cuisine. In Japan cod and pollock roe are cured with chilli and called mentaiko. The colour is bright red and it is the perfect partner to many things. Eating out in Ireland can be a little difficult when you canâ€™t have dairy. It is entirely possible and people are of course very accommodating.Â On an island of farmers and in a food culture devoted to all things butter milk and cream, it has felt in recent years like I have been missing a lot.

Cork has a rich dairy history. It was once home to the most important butter market in the UK and Ireland. Launched in 1730, at its peak in the 1880s it was handling 500,000 casks of butter per year valued at Â£1.5million. People travelled from all over the world to Cork to trade butter.Â It is for this reason that there are recipes like Spiced Beef in Cork as the spices were traded for butter. It closed later as European butter markets competed, and in the area where it once thrived there is now Cork Butter Museum. A curious small place packed with butter paraphernalia and history including an ancient barrel of bog butter. Butter was our primary source of fat and therefore stored energy for the lean months of winter. We are still obsessed.

The sauce is coffee and shito, which they described as analogous to sambal, and like anchovy to lamb, this sauce harmonised beautifully with the sheep. For acidity, a purÃ©e of mandarin and sweet potato also graced the plate.

I am very excited to see fish head appear more regularly on London menus these days, because all the best bits are here! The cuisson is spot on, all the gelatinous bits sliding off the bone, and given the rich natural flavours, the spices do amazing things to temper it. Iâ€™d go as far to say itâ€™s the best fish head Iâ€™ve had in London. Comes close to many childhood memories of fish head curries back home.
(Moan as much as you like about the prices but River Cafe (and T Randall) do very good versions of Turbot tranche in their wood fire oven too)

As with Logy, the team is seen at the end of lunch service, starting the meats on the pan for the dinner service. To colour, prior to a slow roast to achieve the consistent edge to edge pink across the meat.
Tahara sanâ€™s piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance for this meal: 100 day old White Roman Goose from Tainan, free range and finished on a diet of barley.

The ode to Taiwanese terroir is ever present in the dish, the goose is paired with potatoes made into a light bloodcake (a nod to the famed Taiwanese street food), and topped with charred Yilan famous â€œ3 starâ€ chives. The duck jus is made with white port and Shao Xing wine.
As we winded down for puds, Tahara san starts the goose for the evening sitting on the pan; a good 4hours prior to dinner service, which is how I got the videos.

Chef Tim Graham pays homage to famed American author Mark Twain with this cozy Logan Square eatery serving updated Midwestern fare. Inspired by his Missouri upbringingâ€”which is also where Mark Twain hailedâ€”Graham puts his own spin on dishes like surf and turf, the Wedge salad and Pigs in a Blanquette. For the former, he finesses it with home-style meatloaf, barbecue unagi and nori-crusted onion rings. Desserts are homey as well, from hand-cranked, seasonal ice cream paired with sheet cake to gooey butter cake topped with seasonal fruit like rosemary roasted peaches.

Feed: While many restaurants and hot spots and newcomers throughout the city peddle buzzy interpretations of fried chicken, Feed has been perfecting the comfort food formula for years. The frills-free, Southern-inspired eatery in Humboldt Park is still among the best destinations for chicken in any form in Chicago. The rotisserie chicken is a popular go-to, but donâ€™t shy away from the fried birds either, especially the dark meat portions. If youâ€™re really feeling hungry, order the 1/2 chicken with two sides, with savorous options like corn pudding, fried okra, succotash, potato salad and mac & cheese.

Chicken & Farm Shop: Nestled inside Soho House Chicago, youâ€™ll find a pastoral restaurant capable of transporting you and your senses to the English countryside. Decked out like a sunny, serene cottage, Chicken & Farm Shop knows a thing or two about comfort in all forms. In addition to the heartwarming ambience, that notion is evident in the menu offerings too. As the name suggests, chicken is king here, and the kitchen has a particular penchant for frying. Nuggets, sandwiches and buttermilk battered chicken and waffles are all on hand, offering different takes on the staple.

The Roost: Armed with a food truck and some family recipes, North Carolina native Joe Scroggs began a fried chicken revolution in Chicago when he took his fiery fried chicken recipe to the streets on his popular food truck. In 2012, The Roost branched out well beyond its food truck roots and into a Â restaurant space at the northern tip of Lakeview, serving signature hot or herb-seasoned fried chicken with buttermilk biscuits and peach cobbler.

: When one of the most acclaimed restaurants in the world opens a restaurant with fried chicken as a star attraction, itâ€™s safe to assume that itâ€™s going to be above-average chicken, to say the least. The folks behind Alinea put fried chicken in a whole new spotlight at Roister, where the humble comfort food ascends to glorious new levels. The highly Instagrammable dish is part of a multi-step whole-chicken preparation thatâ€™s served with sunchokes and chamomile, and thereâ€™s also a more casual fried chicken sandwich that gets a punch of sunchoke hot sauce and some fragrant chamomile mayo.

: When most people think of Tex-Mex, be it classic and no-frills or totally neoteric and adventurous, they think of enchiladas and tacos and tequila. Fried chicken may not be the most obvious go-to, but it fits in well at Doveâ€™s Luncheonette, which does a top-notch job with clever Tex-Mex in Wicker Park. A nod to chicken-fried steak, a Texas staple, the chicken-fried chicken was an instant hit at the sunny restaurant, and it remains as fiendishly popular as ever. Thatâ€™s thanks to the comforting combo of buttermilk fried chicken and creamy, spicy chorizo verde gravy. The heaping plate gets a welcome dose of brightness and sweetness thanks to peas and pearl onions.

: Seafood gets top billing at this familial, nautically inspired Lincoln Park haunt, but youâ€™d remiss to skim over the fried chicken, which is a real sleeper hit on the expansive menu. The rendition here contains a hulking portion of crispy chicken seasoned with Old Bay spices, served with sides of cole slaw and fries. Those spices are key, adding just the right mix of heat and herbs. For those looking for fried chicken at home, the restaurant also offers the same chicken to-go from its adjoining carryout and delivery concept, Seasideâ€™s.

: Just above the waterside Chicagoâ€™s most iconic location for dining with a soaring view is undoubtedly The Signature Room. Unless youâ€™re paralyzed by a fear of heights, that is, because in order to get to the restaurant youâ€™ll need to ascend an elevator to the 95th floor of the John Hancock. Once here, youâ€™ll savor modern American cuisine with a seasonal tilt, plus craft cocktails, wine and beer. No matter where youâ€™re seated, youâ€™ll be rewarded with majestic, awe-inspiring views of Lake Michigan and the skyline. The best seats in the house, though, are the ones perched up against the north-facing glass wall, which affords a stunning vista of Chicagoâ€™s beach-lined north side.

: One of the most criminally underrated restaurants when it comes to sky-high dining in Chicago, Cite gets you so close to the lake you may actually feel like you could fall in. Located on the 70th floor Â of Lake Point Tower, the only skyscraper east of Lake Shore Drive, and just in front of Navy Pier, the soaring restaurant has extraordinary views from every angle. The seafood, steaks, cocktails and tasting menus arenâ€™t too shabby, either. Using French techniques and a seasonal mentality, the restaurant features ever-changing dishes like lobster tail with butter gnocchi, sesame-crusted Alaskan salmon, venison strip loin with poached pear and rack of lamb with ratatouille.

: When it comes to beachy dining in the city, it doesnâ€™t get much better â€” or beachier â€” than Caffe Oliva. This bright and sunny cafe is literally located right on Ohio Street Beach alongside Navy Pier, providing a warm, relaxing vibe to your patio dining experience. This yearâ€™s menu is better than ever, featuring an eclectic lineup of shareable plates like Greek bruschetta, fried calamari with lime aioli, coconut shrimp, margherita flatbreads, blackened whitefish with tzatziki and a slew of sandwiches and burgers. Thereâ€™s also a kidsâ€™ menu, desserts, brunch and a ton of cocktails. Keep the group party going with one of Caffe Olivaâ€™s fish bowls, designed to satisfy a thirsty group with potions like the â€œFinding Nemoâ€: blueberry vodka, pineapple juice, sour, fresh lemon juice and Swedish fish.

Pinstripes: If the idea of dining and drinking at a bowling alley sounds like a joke to you, then clearly you havenâ€™t spent any time at a Pinstripes. This beloved mini-chain is popular for good reason, and their Streeterville location (the only one in city limits) backs it all up with the added bonus of being right on the Ogden Slip harbor, with a lengthy fire pit-lined patio overlooking the lake. In addition to bowling and bocce inside, Pinstripes sets itself apart as a restaurant destination in and of itself, with casual yet inventive Italian food thatâ€™s great both for snacking-while-gaming and for a leisurely meal al fresco or indoors.

: For upscale Italian fare with an equally impressive vista, donâ€™t miss Cafe Spiaggia. Or really if youâ€™re feeling decadent, itâ€™s even more upscale sister restaurant Spiaggia. But due to its more accessible offerings, Cafe Spiaggia is certainly an easier stopover for a quick lunch with a sensational overlooking the top of the Magnificent Mile and Oak Street Beach. The restaurant offers a contemporary, elegant take on classic Italian cuisine, making for a fine meal while nestled along the windows above one of the most famous shopping streets in the country.

. The South Loop outpost of the boil-in-a-bag seafood concept, which specializes in Cajun-style shellfish, has added weekend brunch to its popular portfolio. A slight departure from its usual eat-with-your-hands bag-centric menu, the brunch offerings span a spectrum of Southern comforts, from fried green tomatoes and pimento cheese to snow crab cake Benedict, biscuits and gravy, shrimp and grits and chicken and waffles. Of course those seafood boils will still be available as an option, filled with customizable provisions like sausage, crab and shrimp. Cheesy grits, honey butter cornbread and garlic beignets are available as sides. For something sweet, opt for the deep-fried Oreos, and wash it all down with a mimosa, Bloody Mary or a quenching highball. Brunch is served Saturdays and Sundays from noon until 3:00 p.m.

has been a smash hit since it debuted last year, racking up the accolades and drawing hordes of diners for its glam dinner service. Now, the glitzy Gold Coast bastion has added breakfast and brunch, providing even more opportunities to sample the decadence. The weekday breakfast menu consists of various toasts (avocado, tahini-banana-honey and smoked salmon), plus pastries aplenty, wholesome bowls (yogurt with muesli and peaches or acai with raw coconut and goji berries) and specialties like asparagus and fontina omelettes, ham and hashbrown Benedict, black truffle scrambled eggs and shirred eggs Florentine. Come weekend brunch, the breakfast lineup is adjoined by a series of lunch-y items, like Brussels sprouts leaves salad with mustard vinaigrette and Medjool dates, Yangâ€™s Imperial lobster toast with caviar and beef Wellington with mushroom bordelaise.

has rolled out a brand new breakfast menu. Already regarded as a power lunch Mecca and steakhouse staple, RLâ€™s new breakfast offerings are sure to be a quick hit for the downtown set. , specifically the bone marrow varuval + paratha is a kind of perfection â€“ More than enough words for a restaurant already over-showered with praise.

this year revealed Brett Grahamâ€™s consistent form. Even though the menu is quite static, it is one that is executed with extreme precision. Is this still Londonâ€™s best restaurant? Yes, I think so.

in Tokyo where young Kotaro Meguroâ€™s (ex-Quintessence) fish-only restaurant delivered the complete wow factor. ThisÂ will be the first in a series of non-food related entries.Â You might (or might not) be interested in following a fledgling blogger starting out. Ok, so..where do I begin. I love food. Check. I want to write about food. Check. I got WordPress running. Check.â€¦

Itâ€™s now been over a year since Alex Dilling took over the reigns from Arnaud Bignon, and what year it has been for this this charming little restaurant that has survived the decades with its series of chefs. Alex has been working non-stop upping the ante with each passing season, and most recently was rewarded by the bib in maintaining the two star rating of afforded to Abelaâ€™s crowning glory since Bignon first won it in 2013.

Just when I think these guys have set the bar, they find another way to level up, never resting on their laurels. The craft involved blows my mind. This dish â€“ an entree and not pudding â€“ actually works best as a surpriseâ€¦

Is it a candidate for 3 stars today? Probably not, as I feel that Pele is still tweaking his ideas about Cantonese flavours in his cuisine. Also, a couple of docked points for presenting tourists with a sub-standard white truffle that is at the moment (mid Nov 2019) showing very well near its peak season. However as it stands, his cuisine is very attractive, the cuisson is generally spot-on and I would love to revisit to see how he is progressing in due time.

â€¦I really didnâ€™t expect to be, but came away very impressed by this brunch. Gyu don was comfort food 101, some kaffir lime in the bowl of beef and onions on rice. Will have to pop back in for a proper dinner at some point.â€¦

I am a huge fan of Jackson Boxer, as I think his food is modern in that it possesses the right mix of craft, creativity and cool. His link to this restaurant is through Levanâ€™s owner, Nicholas Balfe, who was once upon a time hisâ€¦

restaurant details: website instagram The secret hideout by Nuno Mendes and his right hand man, Edoardo Pellicano, who you will know from Portlandâ€™s beginning days with Merlin. It opened last year, and I visited in Oct 2018, although I spend more time on IG thanâ€¦

If I had to pick one restaurant this year that surprised/excited me, it would most definitely be Abri. Opened by Katsuaki Okiyama in 2012, it is part of the original set of Japanase-French restaurants that has long since become a permanent feature in the Parisâ€¦

Tomos Parryâ€™s Basque inspired BBQ restaurant, with British produce. Named after the mighty turbot, expectedly the star attraction here is the slow-grilled whole turbot, in the style of famous restaurants, such as say Elkano in Getaria, Northern Spain. Iâ€™ve been three times now, and Iâ€¦

If you follow me on Instagram (likely where we both spend most of the time food-hunting these days), then youâ€™ll know I love a good sarnie. It is an art unto itself, and IMHO the pleasure a great sandwich gives, can be equal to theâ€¦

Thought not her originally chosen path, she follows in the footsteps of her grandfather Andre, her father Jacques and eventually took over the kitchen from her brother Alain in 1998. She received the coveted 3 stars in her own right in 2007. She also owns another eponymous restaurant in Lausanne which currently holds 2 stars. No small feat considering there are not many female chefs in pro kitchens, let alone ones who have reached the pinnacle of their profession. We do have Clare Smyth over here, who will hopefully open her own doors, in the Summer. Much in the spirit of the great Eugenie Brazier and Marie Bourgeois.

This is my first visit to a Pic restaurant, she does have many well-known dishes floating around the web that identifies her style as her own, with the incorporation of ingredients where you may, lets say, not expect them in a classic sense. Not to mention her striking puddings, and I think particularly of the chocolate lattice and also the all-white millefeuille.

Some of her top-end stuff (including the MF) as well as her family classics makes appearances at Dame London, and for this, she has entrusted it to an Italian, Luca Piscazzi. He has La Pergola (Romeâ€™s only 3 star), Amber HK and Apsleys, the previous occupant restaurant at Lanesborough before Eric Frechon moved in, on his resume.

The wine list isâ€¦ expensive. I note that they do Latour BTG, on this visit, 2004 at Â£185 for 125ml. This translates to a bottle price of Â£1110, which would be at least the 3x mark-up (to be optimistic). Bottom line is one thing, but value for money (compared to market price) is another, but I think this is a little too much for a relatively young Latour and especially considering the private club in the hotel is organised around the first growth, I expect more of a deal. For that money, at least a 2000 perhaps. The wine list (and the Latour discovery room) is looked after by somm Jan Konetzki, who has joined from Gordon Ramsay RHR.

Meanwhile in the restaurant â€“ in keeping with London â€“ they have laid out a brasserie-like room that walks the tight rope of being gastronomic business and gastronomic casual. Brown leather banquettes, towering pillars of stained glass and triple height ceilings.
We visit for friday lunch, and ordered a 3 course meal. My brother ate from the lunch concessions (Â£39 for three) and I ate from the ALC.

Grilled to golden brown crust and soft centre. Classically paired with a hollandaise, albeit mildly infused with curry. Yes. Lovely work really and a good shout to stick these spears for the lunch set menu. The white asparagus from the south of France now starting to come into peak season, that is to say quality and also a dive in prices.

â€˜s purer style is awesome, but of course, Picâ€™s preparation is equally a quality treatment for the noble product. For those who bang on about quality produce, this is one such specimen. In fact outside of Hedone and Bonhams, I donâ€™t know if any other London restaurant offers Live abalone. I hope you guys eat more of it, so more chefs over here will offer it. Theyâ€™re not as glamorous as Ise or Australian, but Irish and Breton abalones are pretty decent, in the right hands.
Given the price tag, I would have liked Wye, Pertuis or perhaps even Roque-Hautes, used at her other restaurants. These Kent ones were tasty nevertheless.

The bill came to Â£162.32 for 2 people for all food, 1 beer, 1 glass of Alsatian Pinot Blanc, a bottle of water and service. The set lunch half of the bill was around Â£50, and an ALC meal came in at Â£110.

Hello folks, I am officially back from my month long vacation, trust you have applied yourselves positively while Iâ€™ve been away. My yearly visit to the folks is always enlightening if perspective bending though this is the first time in eight years that I went home in time to celebrate Chinese New Year. Iâ€™m carrying alot of holiday weight right now, five kilos to be exact, heavy stuff. Astrologists are predicting a gold rush this year and have interpreted the year of the Metal Tiger to be one made of solid gold. Bling. I had originally intended this post to be the closer to my run of unofficial Chinese New Year write-ups and was suppose to coincide with Chap Go Meh â€“ the fifteenth day of the new Lunar year â€“ the same day which also marks the end of the Chinese New year festivalâ€¦ but other more pressing commitments had ensured a five day delay â€“ building websites still doesnâ€™t quite pay the rent. I had spent most of the time travelling between Brunei, Singapore and Taiwan, the latter was where I decided to spend my money. I have good reason to stuff myself silly and I filled my schedule with pit-stops to restaurants which served something representatively local â€“ like a crash course into the native cuisine. Itâ€™s all well and good that we have so many restaurants which cater to all sorts of world cuisines, but it occurred to me that London has been the first destination that I have sampled certain international flavours. Something as common as say pizza for example â€“ I canâ€™t say Iâ€™ve actually tried a Neapolitan recipe passed down from the ages. This holiday would double as gastronomic adventure and I view it as a way to build my CV in a particular style of cuisine, so that Iâ€™ll always have something to compare my London exploits against. And so Kangâ€™s quest to catch a glimpse into the world of Taiwanese cuisine was born. Here are his notes (So weird writing in the third person).

The scene is Taipei. The capital of the island republic, it is situated on the Northern tip of the country and its name unsurprisingly translates to â€˜Northern Taiwanâ€™. Home to 2.6 million, it is an emerging ultra modern metropolis of Blade Runner style concrete jungle and itâ€™s skyline proudly accomodates Taipei 101, once the tallest building in the world. Like all cities, there are shades of vintage buildings still lingering underneath all the shiny metal and glass. Old shop houses prop up the neon signs, lighting up the cityâ€™s night like a Christmas tree. Itâ€™s wonderfully urban, tight street corners just wide enough for cars to pass through and temperamental rainclouds which make London feel like Cyprus. In the belly of the beast lies a diverse range of restaurant, cafÃ©s and their famed night markets which play host to hundreds of independent street food vendors making it a sort of foodieâ€™s wet dream. In fact, there is so much diversity in itâ€™s food, a week is simply not enough time to try everything. But I tried anyway. My excursion wouldnâ€™t be as impactful if not for my extended family taking me around the city, so I have the C and Câ€™s to thank for all the recs.

With Londoners experiencing a spike in Sichuan food, I thought itâ€™d be appropriate that our first stop was Chuan Ba Zhe â€“ a Szechuan restaurant that does all-you-can-eat â€˜Ma-laâ€™ hotpots for about 8 per head.

The local flavour â€“ Gold Medal Beer. The brew is light and carries a chrysanthemum sweetness about it â€“ very easy drinking stuff. We started with a selection of â€˜small dishesâ€™ to share dishes and to start â€“ something which is characteristic of a Taiwanese meal â€“ including Kousiu (Saliva) chicken , Quaiwei (weird taste) vermicelli, Dou gan zhe (bean curd slices) and Mala tripe. As it was a Szechuan restaurant, everything was red in colour, evident of potent sliced chilli everywhere and the tranquilising effect of Szechuan pepper slowly started to grab hold of my tastebuds. Terrifying.
The main highlight of the meal was the all-you-can-eat hotpot, the freeloading aspect in that we could order as much meat or vegetables we wanted to chuck into the soup.

in Earls Court, youâ€™ll be able get your hands on a Ma-la hotpot. Itâ€™s usually protocol to have a layer of oil floating on top of the soup, itâ€™s suppose to keep the heat in and also to cook whatever youâ€™ve dunked into the soup. I am certain that London restaurants hold back on the peppers â€“ this place didnâ€™t.

We rode the MRT â€“ Taipeiâ€™s equivalent of the tube â€“ to Danshui and to the very end of the line. The town is a scenic getaway from the high tech city of Taipei. Here, people rolled around in vespas and flip flops and beyond the bridges, you can watch fishermen barbecueing their triumphs by the beach. Restaurants lined the coast, and as we went on a Sunday, it was as if all of Taipei had descended upon this area. We had trekked all the way here to visit the Black Shop, and to sample the locally celebrated pork chop rice.

A large bowl of their signature pork chop costs two pounds, less if our political system was in better working order. Like all umami infused food â€“ this bowl of rice smelled hearty, rustic and fragrant. Served piping hot, the large flap of chop garnished with bean braised tofu and pickled cabbage that carried a vinegary stink. The rice was glutinous, almost sushi rice (but I darenâ€™t claim it) and the savoury flouriness of the pork chop was unmistakable. There was a thin outer which encapsulated the piece of meat, eggs must have been used and the coating absorbed alot of moisture leading to a juiciness which softened the texture of the pork. The combination of the bean-flavoured tofu, the vinegary pickled cabbage and the soya infused egginess of the porkchop gave way to an exemplary example of umamiâ€¦ I finished two bowls.

The black shop was still entertaining massive queues at 3pm in the afternoon, and this was a huge restaurant spread over two floors â€“ such was the popularity of itâ€™s pork chop rice. While there, it was also an opportunity to give one of Taiwanâ€™s best â€“ if common â€“ small dishes a try : Cold creamy tofu with sweet century egg.

We headed out bright and early the next day so that I could run a few errands while in Taipei. Things are generally cheaper, I had my Seiko Kinetic fixed for just under Â£40 compared to a whopping Â£85 minimum if I sent it to Maidenhead. I also had bought a pair of thick black rimmed glasses â€“ Clark Kent style â€“ for a reasonable priceâ€¦. yes, as if Gary Rhodes would suddenly recognised me attempting to â€˜reviewâ€™ his restaurant, says my ego.

I spent alot of time getting lost in the side streets which hid makeshift markets and the occasional street food vendor, photographing this street life proved to be one of the highlights of my visit to Taipei.

I think the thick gravy â€“ slimy and very fishy â€“ was probably made from the juices scallop and the oyster. It was like a runny pizza with a dough that absorbed too much moisture. Very potent, I could only have a slice before the fishiness became overwhelming.
So that was my trip to Taipei. The most memorable meal has got to be the Pork Chop rice â€“ simple food, but oh so good. In addition to this, I wrote up on one of Taiwanâ€™s greatest treasure â€“
Very interesting blog post â€“ Taiwanese food is not something you hear a lot about. Makes me want to explore tofu a whole lot more though, particularly as a seasoning.

Wild Boar â€“ The place is called Da Jia Hao (or everybody good in chinese!). You come out of the MRT station Dingxi (MRT Orange Line) , I think itâ€™s exit number 1, up the escalator, its on the left hand side and you will see the place â€˜through the windowâ€™ as you are going up the escalatorâ€¦. more confusing that it sounds, but trust me it should make more sense when you guys get there, basically itâ€™s in a separate building just outside the station ðŸ™‚ Ahhâ€¦ when you are in DingXi make sure try THE original soya milk shop called â€˜Dou Jiang Da Wangâ€™. The directionsâ€¦ are difficult to describe, but itâ€™s a five minute walk from the station (Dingxi) and any local in the area should know this place, very popularâ€¦ ok good luck and hope you enjoy it!!!
An American in London â€“ Taipei is a great place for food, so much to eat! Zen bing? Is the bread white, soft and fluffy? Nope, donâ€™t think I tried it on this trip!

Oh not fluffy, etc.  Zen bing really is like a burrito.  You get a flour pancake (almost like a flour tortilla, but a bit tougher â€“ hot off the griddle), and itâ€™s filled with a little rice, veg, egg, chinese sausage â€“ whatever you like, really.  The best part, in my opinion, was always the crushed peanuts/peanut powder to add crunch and sweet nuttiness.  Itâ€™s great stuff and Iâ€™d recommend looking out for it next time youâ€™re in Tapiei.  [I used to spend summers in Taipei when I was little.]

This is such a great post, Taiwanese food is always so flavoursome and seasoned! I wonder if you ever found hujiao bing in London, can you let me know?

The 2019 prices have risen nearly across the board, though quality remains ever so high here at Lâ€™Arpege. Spontaneity and creativity reign supreme, Passard and his kitchen still immensely spirited in their practice of gastronomy at the highest levels, they continue to introduce new dishes to their menu, not bad for a restaurant now in its 33rd year. As usual, Tony Beldroega was in charge of the affairs today, with the Chef himself making an appearance mid-way through lunch to greet punters. I had wanted to try Alainâ€™s latest Frankenstein creation, the Chimera, pigeon stiched together with a rack of lamb, but alas it wasnâ€™t on the menu on this visit.

As you might be familiar, the lunch menu is essentially themed around whatever vegetables they have in abundance from Alainâ€™s two gardens. They tend to repeat themselves over the course of the longish meal. In the case of this meal, yellow round courgettes and white asparagus appeared to be at peak. If you arrive at the restaurant around 11ish, youâ€™ll see the little white van delivering their daily haul of greens.

Lâ€™Arpege is a restaurant that continues to enthrall me, the cuisine is very much based on improvisation and it is very rustic and homely in many ways, the antithesis of rehearsed, static crafted tasting menus. The food here is fine in its eating, while the dishes are beautiful to look at, the kitchen spends the majority cooking rather than plating little things perfectly. Some people do not like it for this very reason, but I love Lâ€™Arpege because at the heart of it all, the restaurant is about pure cooking, slow grilled proteins cooked grand and whole, and daring la minute preparations for everything else. It might seem counter intuitive to say this, but in todayâ€™s world of foraged, water bath modernism, Lâ€™Arpege is in the minority when it comes to actually delivering hot food on piping hot plates. A pre-requisite as it always should be for any fine food that is cooked with love and respect!

As you must already be aware from the in-trend BBQ hispis that grace many restaurants today, this caramalised cabbage too transformed its raw, crunchy sweetness into something significantly more complex â€“ meaty, smoky, fully softened yet remaining juicy at the very same time, suped up savouriness.

Of course the secret here is their supremely fine puff pastry, so delicate in its flakiness, that it gifts the tatin a soft and smooth texture, collapsing like a hot knife through butter with the gentlest push. An embodiment of the genius comfort food and the exquisite craft of Lâ€™Arpege.

They are technically not seasonal and are indeed avaiable all year round. But Lobsters in the English Channel between Dorset and Brittany are at their best around the summer, starting from say June and run till August. July is probably the most plentiful month, and prices are cheapest. I did have the lobster vin jaune in November last year.
with a series of images that were taken completely inside the various restaurants that I had visited throughout 2009 and 2010. You might even recognise some dishes in these photographs.

entirely in portrait orientation, and all are based on the 8Ã—10 frame, as opposed to the 8x11ish full-frame that the 35mm format offers. Iâ€™ve done so because I feel that the 8Ã—10 frame emphasises food very well, itâ€™s shorter and a more logical frame to meâ€¦ plus it fits an A4 page very well.
I also keep a number of photography related articles on my portfolio site â€“ like using a Leica M9 to shoot food for instance â€“ so please feel free to pay a visit to
if you like my food photography (or just like staring at food photos in general) and please keep me in mind if you have a photography job to carry out. Especially if you are a restaurant.

Kang Kang Kang. The way you reel off all these amazing food pictures makes it seem like its so easy to you. 8 x 10 is a nice format and only the other day I was looking at some out our pics thinking that something was off on the frame dimensions. Maybe this is my answer. And I should get a better lens. And a better flash. And maybe I should read a book. *Sigh*

ish and chips is a national symbol.Â The reason I say so is because everybody has their own personal experience of it. If you ask someone where their favourite chippie is, youâ€™ll get this long gaze (like heâ€™s going down memory lane),Â with a lowered voice,Â they goÂ â€˜i know this placeâ€¦â€™. You can tell from their facial expressions how much they enjoy it.

I grew up in a really small town on the other side of the world and as far away from england as can be. But you know, I still remember my first brush with the old fish and chip combo. It was in a â€˜western restaurantâ€™, as they are call it in asia, that servedÂ steaksÂ roast chicken and the like.Â I orderedÂ a large haddock and chips.

Established in 1939, according to esteemed crtics,Â it was a regular spot for old colleagues to unwind for a long, lazy lunch. Last year, this place was taken over by the genius team of mark fuller and andy taylor with gary hollihead applying his michelin starred skills in the kitchen. Geales is about a 5 minute walk from notting hill gate tube and is conveniently tucked away behind the cinema.

are attempting a similar thing. You can even findÂ an excellent exampleÂ at belgoâ€™s in covent garden. Though, I think the main difference at geales is that fish and chips takes centre stage.Â This hardworking dish has seemingly been givenÂ a slick makeover, abit likeÂ howÂ a nostalgic tv show gets the silver screen treatment. Think charlieâ€™s angels, erm, mission impossible?Â AnotherÂ great chef, Tom Aikens of chelsea attempted it in similar fashion at tomâ€™s place, it would have beenÂ nice toÂ tryÂ it, but sadly, the neighbours very recently brought about a shock closure.
to read about the co stars and if its added sparkle to the mix. So on to the food. We order double portion chips, double mushy peas on the side. I had the cod and Nic went with the haddock.

I believe the secret to getting really good chips is to double fry them, so they are crispy on the outside and use top quality spudsÂ like maris piper to make themÂ soft and fluffy on the inside. Just look at the chips, they areÂ an absolute beautyÂ and they taste great. But thereâ€™s the issue of price, thatâ€™s aÂ double portion that costs Â£6. Its abit steep, granted they do taste good, but is itÂ justifiableÂ paying a Â£5 premium to get chips that taste marginally better than burger king?

I hear thumping,â€Dinner in half an hourâ€ its my mumâ€™s voice coming from the kitchen. Sheâ€™s tenderlising meat the old fashion way. Iâ€™m twelve and Iâ€™m running around the house, and i hear the sizzling sparkles, my mum is pan frying her world famous thinly sliced steaks. Dinner time, my brother and I runÂ to the table.Â What is that gorgeous smell?

For me, itâ€™s fried chicken with fried dumplings (we called crumbs), mashed potatoes, and green beans. My mom first soaked the chicken in milk, then diped them in flour seasoned with Lawryâ€™s seasoning salt. Then, they went into the hot oil of the frying pan. Sheâ€™d mix the leftover milk with the leftover flour to make a paste and then dropped the paste in little dots into the same oil. These â€œcrumbsâ€ are, by far, my most favorite make me smile food memory.

Thought not her originally chosen path, she follows in the footsteps of her grandfather Andre, her father Jacques and eventually took over the kitchen from her brother Alain in 1998. She received the coveted 3 stars in her own right in 2007. She also owns another eponymous restaurant in Lausanne which currently holds 2 stars. No small feat considering there are not many female chefs in pro kitchens, let alone ones who have reached the pinnacle of their profession. We do have Clare Smyth over here, who will hopefully open her own doors, in the Summer. Much in the spirit of the great Eugenie Brazier and Marie Bourgeois.

This is my first visit to a Pic restaurant, she does have many well-known dishes floating around the web that identifies her style as her own, with the incorporation of ingredients where you may, lets say, not expect them in a classic sense. Not to mention her striking puddings, and I think particularly of the chocolate lattice and also the all-white millefeuille.

Some of her top-end stuff (including the MF) as well as her family classics makes appearances at Dame London, and for this, she has entrusted it to an Italian, Luca Piscazzi. He has La Pergola (Romeâ€™s only 3 star), Amber HK and Apsleys, the previous occupant restaurant at Lanesborough before Eric Frechon moved in, on his resume.

The wine list isâ€¦ expensive. I note that they do Latour BTG, on this visit, 2004 at Â£185 for 125ml. This translates to a bottle price of Â£1110, which would be at least the 3x mark-up (to be optimistic). Bottom line is one thing, but value for money (compared to market price) is another, but I think this is a little too much for a relatively young Latour and especially considering the private club in the hotel is organised around the first growth, I expect more of a deal. For that money, at least a 2000 perhaps. The wine list (and the Latour discovery room) is looked after by somm Jan Konetzki, who has joined from Gordon Ramsay RHR.

Meanwhile in the restaurant â€“ in keeping with London â€“ they have laid out a brasserie-like room that walks the tight rope of being gastronomic business and gastronomic casual. Brown leather banquettes, towering pillars of stained glass and triple height ceilings.
We visit for friday lunch, and ordered a 3 course meal. My brother ate from the lunch concessions (Â£39 for three) and I ate from the ALC.

Grilled to golden brown crust and soft centre. Classically paired with a hollandaise, albeit mildly infused with curry. Yes. Lovely work really and a good shout to stick these spears for the lunch set menu. The white asparagus from the south of France now starting to come into peak season, that is to say quality and also a dive in prices.

â€˜s purer style is awesome, but of course, Picâ€™s preparation is equally a quality treatment for the noble product. For those who bang on about quality produce, this is one such specimen. In fact outside of Hedone and Bonhams, I donâ€™t know if any other London restaurant offers Live abalone. I hope you guys eat more of it, so more chefs over here will offer it. Theyâ€™re not as glamorous as Ise or Australian, but Irish and Breton abalones are pretty decent, in the right hands.
Given the price tag, I would have liked Wye, Pertuis or perhaps even Roque-Hautes, used at her other restaurants. These Kent ones were tasty nevertheless.

The bill came to Â£162.32 for 2 people for all food, 1 beer, 1 glass of Alsatian Pinot Blanc, a bottle of water and service. The set lunch half of the bill was around Â£50, and an ALC meal came in at Â£110.

The full prices may make you wince, but I must say that they have put quite some effort into their lunch menus and provide ample value for money, considering whatâ€™s on the plate. The weekday 3 courses for Â£39 is superb, but the next time I return, I will be looking closely at the Weekend 4 course lunch for Â£55. Both the sole and millefeuille are on the weekend lunch set. Well worth a visit.

with a series of images that were taken completely inside the various restaurants that I had visited throughout 2009 and 2010. You might even recognise some dishes in these photographs.

entirely in portrait orientation, and all are based on the 8Ã—10 frame, as opposed to the 8x11ish full-frame that the 35mm format offers. Iâ€™ve done so because I feel that the 8Ã—10 frame emphasises food very well, itâ€™s shorter and a more logical frame to meâ€¦ plus it fits an A4 page very well.

Hello folks, I am officially back from my month long vacation, trust you have applied yourselves positively while Iâ€™ve been away. My yearly visit to the folks is always enlightening if perspective bending though this is the first time in eight years that I went home in time to celebrate Chinese New Year. Iâ€™m carrying alot of holiday weight right now, five kilos to be exact, heavy stuff. Astrologists are predicting a gold rush this year and have interpreted the year of the Metal Tiger to be one made of solid gold. Bling. I had originally intended this post to be the closer to my run of unofficial Chinese New Year write-ups and was suppose to coincide with Chap Go Meh â€“ the fifteenth day of the new Lunar year â€“ the same day which also marks the end of the Chinese New year festivalâ€¦ but other more pressing commitments had ensured a five day delay â€“ building websites still doesnâ€™t quite pay the rent. I had spent most of the time travelling between Brunei, Singapore and Taiwan, the latter was where I decided to spend my money. I have good reason to stuff myself silly and I filled my schedule with pit-stops to restaurants which served something representatively local â€“ like a crash course into the native cuisine. Itâ€™s all well and good that we have so many restaurants which cater to all sorts of world cuisines, but it occurred to me that London has been the first destination that I have sampled certain international flavours. Something as common as say pizza for example â€“ I canâ€™t say Iâ€™ve actually tried a Neapolitan recipe passed down from the ages. This holiday would double as gastronomic adventure and I view it as a way to build my CV in a particular style of cuisine, so that Iâ€™ll always have something to compare my London exploits against. And so Kangâ€™s quest to catch a glimpse into the world of Taiwanese cuisine was born. Here are his notes (So weird writing in the third person).

The scene is Taipei. The capital of the island republic, it is situated on the Northern tip of the country and its name unsurprisingly translates to â€˜Northern Taiwanâ€™. Home to 2.6 million, it is an emerging ultra modern metropolis of Blade Runner style concrete jungle and itâ€™s skyline proudly accomodates Taipei 101, once the tallest building in the world. Like all cities, there are shades of vintage buildings still lingering underneath all the shiny metal and glass. Old shop houses prop up the neon signs, lighting up the cityâ€™s night like a Christmas tree. Itâ€™s wonderfully urban, tight street corners just wide enough for cars to pass through and temperamental rainclouds which make London feel like Cyprus. In the belly of the beast lies a diverse range of restaurant, cafÃ©s and their famed night markets which play host to hundreds of independent street food vendors making it a sort of foodieâ€™s wet dream. In fact, there is so much diversity in itâ€™s food, a week is simply not enough time to try everything. But I tried anyway. My excursion wouldnâ€™t be as impactful if not for my extended family taking me around the city, so I have the C and Câ€™s to thank for all the recs.

With Londoners experiencing a spike in Sichuan food, I thought itâ€™d be appropriate that our first stop was Chuan Ba Zhe â€“ a Szechuan restaurant that does all-you-can-eat â€˜Ma-laâ€™ hotpots for about 8 per head.

The local flavour â€“ Gold Medal Beer. The brew is light and carries a chrysanthemum sweetness about it â€“ very easy drinking stuff. We started with a selection of â€˜small dishesâ€™ to share dishes and to start â€“ something which is characteristic of a Taiwanese meal â€“ including Kousiu (Saliva) chicken , Quaiwei (weird taste) vermicelli, Dou gan zhe (bean curd slices) and Mala tripe. As it was a Szechuan restaurant, everything was red in colour, evident of potent sliced chilli everywhere and the tranquilising effect of Szechuan pepper slowly started to grab hold of my tastebuds. Terrifying.
The main highlight of the meal was the all-you-can-eat hotpot, the freeloading aspect in that we could order as much meat or vegetables we wanted to chuck into the soup.

in Earls Court, youâ€™ll be able get your hands on a Ma-la hotpot. Itâ€™s usually protocol to have a layer of oil floating on top of the soup, itâ€™s suppose to keep the heat in and also to cook whatever youâ€™ve dunked into the soup. I am certain that London restaurants hold back on the peppers â€“ this place didnâ€™t.

We rode the MRT â€“ Taipeiâ€™s equivalent of the tube â€“ to Danshui and to the very end of the line. The town is a scenic getaway from the high tech city of Taipei. Here, people rolled around in vespas and flip flops and beyond the bridges, you can watch fishermen barbecueing their triumphs by the beach. Restaurants lined the coast, and as we went on a Sunday, it was as if all of Taipei had descended upon this area. We had trekked all the way here to visit the Black Shop, and to sample the locally celebrated pork chop rice.

A large bowl of their signature pork chop costs two pounds, less if our political system was in better working order. Like all umami infused food â€“ this bowl of rice smelled hearty, rustic and fragrant. Served piping hot, the large flap of chop garnished with bean braised tofu and pickled cabbage that carried a vinegary stink. The rice was glutinous, almost sushi rice (but I darenâ€™t claim it) and the savoury flouriness of the pork chop was unmistakable. There was a thin outer which encapsulated the piece of meat, eggs must have been used and the coating absorbed alot of moisture leading to a juiciness which softened the texture of the pork. The combination of the bean-flavoured tofu, the vinegary pickled cabbage and the soya infused egginess of the porkchop gave way to an exemplary example of umamiâ€¦ I finished two bowls.

The black shop was still entertaining massive queues at 3pm in the afternoon, and this was a huge restaurant spread over two floors â€“ such was the popularity of itâ€™s pork chop rice. While there, it was also an opportunity to give one of Taiwanâ€™s best â€“ if common â€“ small dishes a try : Cold creamy tofu with sweet century egg.

We headed out bright and early the next day so that I could run a few errands while in Taipei. Things are generally cheaper, I had my Seiko Kinetic fixed for just under Â£40 compared to a whopping Â£85 minimum if I sent it to Maidenhead. I also had bought a pair of thick black rimmed glasses â€“ Clark Kent style â€“ for a reasonable priceâ€¦. yes, as if Gary Rhodes would suddenly recognised me attempting to â€˜reviewâ€™ his restaurant, says my ego.

I spent alot of time getting lost in the side streets which hid makeshift markets and the occasional street food vendor, photographing this street life proved to be one of the highlights of my visit to Taipei.

I think the thick gravy â€“ slimy and very fishy â€“ was probably made from the juices scallop and the oyster. It was like a runny pizza with a dough that absorbed too much moisture. Very potent, I could only have a slice before the fishiness became overwhelming.
So that was my trip to Taipei. The most memorable meal has got to be the Pork Chop rice â€“ simple food, but oh so good. In addition to this, I wrote up on one of Taiwanâ€™s greatest treasure â€“
Very interesting blog post â€“ Taiwanese food is not something you hear a lot about. Makes me want to explore tofu a whole lot more though, particularly as a seasoning.

Wild Boar â€“ The place is called Da Jia Hao (or everybody good in chinese!). You come out of the MRT station Dingxi (MRT Orange Line) , I think itâ€™s exit number 1, up the escalator, its on the left hand side and you will see the place â€˜through the windowâ€™ as you are going up the escalatorâ€¦. more confusing that it sounds, but trust me it should make more sense when you guys get there, basically itâ€™s in a separate building just outside the station ðŸ™‚ Ahhâ€¦ when you are in DingXi make sure try THE original soya milk shop called â€˜Dou Jiang Da Wangâ€™. The directionsâ€¦ are difficult to describe, but itâ€™s a five minute walk from the station (Dingxi) and any local in the area should know this place, very popularâ€¦ ok good luck and hope you enjoy it!!!
An American in London â€“ Taipei is a great place for food, so much to eat! Zen bing? Is the bread white, soft and fluffy? Nope, donâ€™t think I tried it on this trip!

Oh not fluffy, etc.  Zen bing really is like a burrito.  You get a flour pancake (almost like a flour tortilla, but a bit tougher â€“ hot off the griddle), and itâ€™s filled with a little rice, veg, egg, chinese sausage â€“ whatever you like, really.  The best part, in my opinion, was always the crushed peanuts/peanut powder to add crunch and sweet nuttiness.  Itâ€™s great stuff and Iâ€™d recommend looking out for it next time youâ€™re in Tapiei.  [I used to spend summers in Taipei when I was little.]

Foodies among you will know of this wonderful food network called foodbuzzÂ where you can make friends with foodies and see what deliciousness is being whipped about in and around the community. Iâ€™ve made lots and lots of new foodie pals over there and generallyâ€¦

It was probably the most intriguing restaurant opening last year. It generated a polarising reception, ranging from those who hailed Nuno Mendesâ€™ travelling fusion food as groundbreaking to others who thought it a purely self indulgent public experiment, injected with an unhealthy dose of pretense.â€¦

The sheer volume of blogposts on Bob Bob Ricard throughout 2010 made the interwebs quite a homogeneous place to read about new things. For a moment in time, BBR was perhaps the trendiest all day, all-booth, Anglo diner in London, complete with

Hawksmoor has great PR, one of the early champions of blogs, it has since gone on to utilise and charm the medium with great success. Generally speaking, you guys â€“ ie, people who read online food ramblings â€“ love Hawksmoor. And I suppose, as aâ€¦

Well, you canâ€™t knock the restaurants around Whitechapel which serve excellent Punjabi food. Of course, I havenâ€™t been to every single one â€“ and who hasnâ€™t tried Tayyabs and Needoo right? â€“ but I think it is safe to say that most deliver food ofâ€¦

Iâ€™m dreaming. This is a radical fantasy, the food is beyond excellent, the filtered water is free, a rainbow assortment of bread flows (freely too) all night long, with the startling choice of salted and unsalted Normandy butter on the table. All hail the newâ€¦

Somewhere along the way, Iâ€™d lost track of what it means to be a food blogger. I rode the chu-chu express along with the rest of the zeitgeist, squeezed my way to the front of the queue for a place at Londonâ€™s trending restaurants, andâ€¦

By now youâ€™ll have tried and failed to book a table at Trullo, the latest budget conscious, laid-back, Italian inspired restaurant to open and to become over-subscribed, in London. Owned by Jordan Frieda, once the front of house at River CafÃ©, and chef Tim Siadatan,

I must confess, I feel pressure writing up my visit to Lâ€™Anima, because as you know, Francesco Mazzeiâ€™s Soul in the city is the gastronomic darling which has had critics, blogs and people who are generally interested in food, cooing in unison. As the consummateâ€¦

Adam Byatt, the thinking manâ€™s version of a celebrity chef, and owner of the much lauded Trinity restaurant, situated in leafy Clapham. Critics adore his work, for the invention, progression and enthusiasm he has brought to British cooking, and one expects no less

I have been itching to supersede my first Goodman post which I wrote last year with something that better reflects my feelings about the restaurant. I love my meat sweats obviously, and in the twelve months following the first visit, Iâ€™ve returned to many aâ€¦

This is one restaurant where I have expended more of my earnings than any other. Before I started writing this blog, Cambio de Tercio was the pay day reward I gave myself at end of every month, it had always turned out to be aâ€¦

For a neighbourhood restaurant, this place sure has a history, not all of the good kind. While there are those of you who reminisce about the good old times, others have only scathing words to say about this Primrose Hill establishment, especially since Mark Powersâ€¦

Here we go once again. This month, the famous Ms Marmite Lover finally enters the fray, Lizzie Mabbot dethrones Chris Pople to go top and the highest climber is The Graphic Foodie to number 13, up by 12. Congratulations to all. Isnâ€™t it more exciting watching the list change leaders now that the all powerful WOM (it is still all powerful, and no list is going to change that right?) has vacated the top spot?

The battered former appearance of the place (ho ho) has now been swept away, and it boasts dÃ©cor in a whole sample-card of shades of grey. The impression this gives is undeniably chic, even if it owes more to New England than to Kensington.

On the eastern fringe of Covent Garden, a smart basement Japanese restaurant with a rather corporate atmosphere and quite high prices (especially on the wine front); for business entertainment, though, it has its attractions, and the lunch menu is a value-proposition well worth seeking out.

It rather seems, then, that this is a restaurant which is not â€“ yet â€“ accustomed to much lunchtime walk-in business. Thatâ€™s a shame, as the lunch menu here is well worth seeking out. We went for the Bento Lunch (Â£17.50), which â€“ in the range and quality of the dishes â€“ is one of the most ambitious we can recall (excluding the ridiculous Hakkasan-group newcomer Crystan, of course, but thatâ€™s another story altogether). The box comprised a range of sushi, and of sashimi, and some cooked fish, as well as a very tasty chicken pancake-sandwich and a bowl of miso soup. If that doesnâ€™t sound very filling, it wasnâ€™t, but the attention to detail, the tastes and the textures were impressive throughout.

Fortunately, then, the Bento box left ample space for a pudding â€“ on the evidence of the elegantly plated assembly of salted caramel ice-cream, pancake and chestnut we enjoyed, these are well worth leaving space for. The waitress even prompted us to have a coffee â€“ she promised, in the face of all the precedents of Japanese restaurants, that it would be goodâ€™ and our espresso was indeed surprisingly impressive.

That coffee was, however, also Â£3, hinting at one key reservation about this place which is that, ÃƒÂ  la carte, the prices seem rather high. In fact, drinking water here â€“ tap was willingly brought â€“ seems a good idea all-round, as even quite modest clarets, for example, quickly whizz past the Â£50 mark. The other major drawback is that, though the setting is comfortable enough, the rather rectilinear layout of this decidedly rectangular basement makes for a setting whose atmosphere tips inescapably towards the corporate.

turned up at a Leeds restaurant in the snowy weather, only to find it closed (she kindly doesnâ€™t name the place). The food was â€œmostly terrificâ€,bar a few timing issues: she described a stewed confit duck leg as â€œtheuber-duck, duck squared, duckiest essence of duckâ€.

The duck (well, he had to order it, just to see what all thefuss â€“ or not â€“ was about) arrived looking like a â€œnewborn babyaccidentally put through a fairground toffee apple machineâ€ and wasserved with â€œreally very wonderful pancakesâ€. The carcass and remaining flesh now come back as a third course (creditto Jay Rayner), cooked in black bean sauce: â€œa deliciously filthy climaxto all that delicate foreplayâ€¦ we picked it bone bare and sat back and sighedâ€.
ventured north to Stoke Newington and the latest inhabitant of a site thatâ€™s seen many restaurants come and go, despite having â€œhigh-footfall berth in a food-literate part of townâ€.

visited Madame Pigg in Haggerston twice, once on a quiet Tuesday and then on a â€œrockingâ€ Friday. On both visits she found â€œfamiliar food ratcheted up by spices and influences from far-off lands executed with cheffy expertise and Ã©lanâ€.

visited Bristol and the Redcliffe sibling to Pasta Loco, which serves only stuffed pasta (itâ€™s the first ravioli restaurant in the country); the mezzaluna of black truffle brought him to â€œtears of joyâ€.

repeated a fellow Telegraph criticâ€™s visit to Lee Westcottâ€™s Netherwood Estate barn conversion on the pretext that he knew the ceramicist whoâ€™d been hired to make some bowls for the restaurant â€“ he took her along too, which was nice.

From the small plates selection (they are big on breakfast and Sundaylunches too), Gaby had Arbroath smokie croquettes that were â€œgorgeousâ€, a â€œheartyâ€ fish pie that was toppedwith mash â€œfluffier than one of Queen Anneâ€™s bunniesâ€ andother comfort food stalwarts; she was less keen on the puddings.
â€œFood suddenly becomes a little less attractive to me, when I see the numbers laid bare and nothing left to the imagination.â€

He enjoyed â€œfeastingfood, a cacophonous delight, the flavours big and bold, the seasoning lustilyappliedâ€ â€“ dish after dish of â€œcomfort food with balls and biteâ€.â€œI adored every bite.â€ On his next visit heâ€™s trying theâ€œlamb intestine curriesâ€¦ venison fries, and devilledâ€¦ well, devilledeverythingâ€. From the S&P people, an upmarket shopping mall-style Thai; its spacious Covent Garden premises offer a pleasant respite from consumerism, even if the food is not consistent enough to make the place a destination in its own right.

Being the only bearer of the brand so far, Suda, of course, is not yet a chain. We assume, however, that this offshoot of the S&P group is a a prototype for a new â€˜diffusionâ€™ multiple to be situated mainly, perhaps exclusively, in upmarket shopping malls â€“ it has that pleasant-enough-but-somehow-no-real-character feeling which seems to be aim of all those who design eating places in or near shopping centres.

Service was unfailingly pleasant, though, and the setting is spacious and comfortable â€“ there are still many much worse places in which you could find yourself, even in this fast-improving part of town.
From the school of Chez Bruce, a (rare) Chelsea restaurant where the emphasis is on the food rather than the ambience â€“ in the light of those priorities, it achieves its aims very well.
We all know restaurant groups have DNA â€“ resemblances between the members of the â€˜familyâ€™ explicable by their common origins. A pretty good example is the â€˜Nigel Platts-Martin groupâ€™.

If you live outside restaurant-land, you may never have heard of this former City solicitor, but heâ€™s just pulled off the remarkable double of being a major stakeholder not only in Chez Bruce (perennially Londonâ€™s Favourite Restaurant, as determined by Hardenâ€™s reporters), but also in the restaurant newly-crowned as the one where you get Londonâ€™s best food, The Ledbury.

On the evidence of Medlar, it seems that restaurant DNA can be acquired â€“ unlike the real sort â€“ simply by propinquity and experience. How else to explain that the new Chelsea restaurant feels, for all practical purposes, just as if Mr Platts-Martin had a share in it? (He definitely doesnâ€™t.)

Thatâ€™s the bad news. The good news is that all the other bits of the DNA have come too, so the menu is full of nice food with a gentle twist, so that you feel you want to eat all the way through it. When the dishes come, youâ€™re not disappointed by the results. And the service, by and large, manages to be there when you want it, and mercifully absent when you donâ€™t. And a very good wine list too.
In short, you might say, Medlar has many of the qualities you might associate with the legendary â€˜perfect neighbourhood restaurantâ€™.

Which begs a very interesting question. When was the last time Chelsea had a real reputation as a good mid-market restaurant neighbourhood? If anything, the Kingâ€™s Road has a bit of a name as the-street-with-no-restaurants. It wasnâ€™t always so, of course. Not that we were there, you understand, but wasnâ€™t there quite a scene there in the â€™60s? That momentum carried on into the â€™80s (when we do sort of remember it).

By the â€™90s, however, the spotlight had begin to move â€˜Up Westâ€™, and â€“ with the odd exception in the environs of Sloane Square â€“ not much has been heard from Chelsea ever since. The area may be full of people who are as rich as Croesus, nowadays, but they do seem rather to have stultified the restaurant scene.

But we digress. Will Medlar work? We hope it will, but â€“ times having moved on since the â€™60s, and even the early days of Chez Bruce, the â€™90s â€“ we must admit we didnâ€™t particularly enjoy eating food of this undoubted quality in surroundings we found slightly uncongenial.

Second surprise? Beyond the basic concept â€“  all-day options, slightly wacky style, flexibility of menu, variety of dining areas, and so on â€“ thereâ€™s nothing obviously Gallic about the formula. And the third? Pace Observer columnist Jay Raynerâ€™s recent views on the subject, New York is clearly the style beacon du jour for many of Londonâ€™s restaurateurs, yet this place manages to avoid many of those Big Apple-style decorative flourishes which are fast becoming clichÃ©s.

This is a shame, as in every other way the service was beyond reproach. We suspect this is a place to which punters will return sufficiently happily that efforts to maximise the revenue from any particular visit are as unnecessary as they are likely, in the longer run, to be counter-productive.
A friendly, independently run sushi bar and Japanese bistro, in a striking setting at the base of a new office building, just north of Broadgate.

We enjoyed both our sushi â€“ presented as a more home-made version in the style you find at Pret â€“ and our scallop curry with copious rice. Presumably the latterâ€™s presentation, a symphony in brown, was authentic. Overall, however, it is the personable style of the operation and the reasonable prices, which â€“ if we worked locally â€“ would be likely to draw us back.

Chancery Lane, the high street of the London legal world, was until very recently, maintaining the English high street tradition of not having restaurants of any note. The situation has improved a bit in recent years, with the arrival in the immediate area of Chancery, and also the very wine-led basement bar and restaurant 28-50.

This essentially English setting has now seen a very Gallic incursion. A restaurant once known by the suitably stolid name of Hodgsonâ€™s has now been taken over by the Club Gascon folk, and given a very French name indeed. Cigalon strikes us as an odd choice, though, echoing as it does that of a Marcel Pagnol movie whose eponymous hero was a ProvenÃƒÂ§al chef whose restaurant remained defiantly empty. Perhaps the French have a sense of humour after all?

The food is not bad, but â€“ like the dÃ©cor â€“ we couldnâ€™t help wondering if it is â€˜rightâ€™. The bread, a selection, was OK, if not at all remarkable, but the overwhelming impression of a bowl of ProvenÃƒÂ§al vegetable soup was that it was rather a ladyâ€™s portion. Our guestâ€™s small portion of marinated sardines similarly failed to cause much excitement.

Main courses were a strikingly bronze-plated dish of red mullet (plus some impressively twiddled-with courgettes), and a relatively substantial veal chop, which our guest ultimately touted as the highlight of the meal. Puddings included a pleasant (if rather could-do-this-at-home) mÃ©lange of citrus fruits and sponge, and a very delicate chocolate tart, somewhat peculiarly presented on a slate platter with what looked like a small deboned fish, but which turned out to be a fancy smear of curd. Our guest pronounced it a moderate success, which was also his view of the coffee.

So what are we to make of a ladiesâ€™ restaurant in the heart of legal london, without either the boho appeal of Club Gascon, or the chic of its Sloane Square satellite, Le Cercle? We sometimes fear we must be missing something.

â€œ[In January] I Â­prefer to shuffle off to a Great Local Restaurant â€“ the kind of near-mythological venue that welcomes you andÂ your slippers with open arms and an uncorked bottle of somethingÂ suitably soothing for under thirty quidâ€¦Â at Llewelynâ€™s in Herne Hill, London SE24 â€“ at the end of a road that I happen to know houses at least two national newspaper restaurant criticsâ€¦Â blow me down â€¦walking past the Â­window â€¦ the esteemed writer and broadcaster Jay Rayner, who then enters the restaurant blowing air-kisses â€“ not to mention what passes for my cover.

â€œThe room is small, comfortable and unpretentious, the whole place infused with a mildly chaotic, genially higgledy-piggledy charmâ€¦Â this is a restaurant where pleasure comes before prissy interior design, and the only commerce that really seems to matter is the serious business of eating.

Undistracted by punters, we had plenty of opportunity to consider the dÃ©cor. This new Italian restaurant is, technically speaking, not really in the NFLYU southern stretch of Audley Street. Itâ€™s on the wrong, northern, side of the social and financial chasm which is Grosvenor Square. (In the distance, you can see â€“ horrors! â€“ Oxford Street.)

(Unless of course the establishment comes complete with a human zoo, like C London, say, and this place doesnâ€™t.)

And so the time came to join the ordinary people in places outside Mayfair. We paid the not inconsiderable bill (service charge added), and the credit card machine kindly gave us the opportunity to add a tip too. Weâ€™re not that stupid you know!

Eat&Read is a weekly round-up of yummi-news from around london and the blogosphere, every Sunday. In the month of January, I ate at ten places in London, discovered a one man bossa nova jukebox, garnered 15000 page views and finally tasted â€˜thatâ€™ Great British puddingâ€¦

The low-lit interior is intriguing, with a single row of dining tables encircling an attractive, slightly sunken bar. Offering an extensive cocktail list, the bar aims to become a destination in its own right. We see potential tensions here. The Miami Beach hotel-lobby music playing the lunchtime we visited, for example, was rather at odds with a restaurant menu whose prices signify serious intent. As the bar fills up on a busy night, the conflict may become stark.

On an early-days lunchtime, however, with the bar empty, the main emphasis was on the food, which fortunately measured up to the prices. Leaving aside a nice-looking basket of home-made breads â€“ which disappointed on the taste front â€“ what was notable was consistent quality of both preparation and presentation of this rich cuisine, even if there was nothing you could call earth-shattering. Service was amiable and efficient too.
All in all then, a useful hide-away in an unlikely location. Be prepared to pay, though, and â€“ if visiting by night â€“ hope that the bar hasnâ€™t become too much of a hit.

On this front, the PR-burble â€“ â€˜racy, raffish and oozing with intrigueâ€™Â â€“  really does seem to have it about right. Londonâ€™s restaurants have come so far over the past 20 years â€“ and particularly the past 10 â€“ that the mere fact that a place offers good food doesnâ€™t necessarily make it of particular interest. How else to explain why we found the latest addition to the Marco Pierre White empire to be both thoroughly competent and completely pointless?

But, first, letâ€™s do the â€˜competentâ€™ bit: the cooking is generally very good. Highlights of a lunch included an unctuous crab bisque, a light and delicious kipper pÃƒÂ¢tÃ©, a beautiful and generous piece of cod and some splendid rib-eye steak. Marcoâ€™s signature lemon tart was also well up to standard. Further to accentuate the positive, the restaurant is handsome and solidly furnished â€“ with that slightly sub-nightclub level of glitz the French often do well â€“ and service is friendly and tries hard.

If you were launching a restaurant on a site like that, youâ€™d probably make darned sure that it had a Unique Selling Proposition â€“ some compelling reason to seek it out. If there is one here, however, it passed us by. Itâ€™s almost as if Marco hasnâ€™t noticed that a lotâ€™s happened in the restaurant world since he built up most of his empire in the â€™90s.

So perhaps Marcoâ€™s got one eye to the locals? Well, the set lunch menu is exceptional value (2 courses for Â£16.50), but weekday business is thin out West (even in Chelsea proper). The weekend could perhaps be a opportunity, but the affluent folk who live round here often have kids. The carte, however, is mainly not child-suitable â€“ oddly, as the place is named after one of his children â€“ and no thought has been given to a kidsâ€™ menu or portions.

It was early days on our Saturday lunchtime visit, but the attendance rather bore out our concerns. Precisely three tables were occupied: one by the great man himself, one by us, and the last by another restaurant critic. There were, in short, no â€˜realâ€™ people there at all. It looks like it will need a lot of very positive reviews to drive enough traffic to make this place a success.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

A relaunch, under unchanged ownership, of a dud former Shoreditch bar-restaurant (Beard to Tail, RIP) which looks set to become a handy all-day destination; our early-days visit was an all-round success, though the new look may not fully be realised till Christmas.

Under unchanged ownership, but new management, the Shoreditch premises once known as Beard-to-Tail still look rather as they did when we reviewed that informal bar-restaurant a year ago, not especially kindly. (Occasionally, we get things right!)

Some of the important things, though, already seem to be going very much in the right direction: this struck us as a very handy sort of informal all-day restaurant even if it still does have a bit of work to do to impress the locals. We lunched pretty much alone. The welcome is warm, and the food - if not especially ambitious - was in a different league from our former visit.

From the daytime menu - essentially a cut-down selection from the evening offering - we were able to try most of the types of dishes on offer. Tasty tomato bread, for example, made a good complement for a fresh-tasting assemblage of peas, beans and Feta-type cheese, and the brace of mini cheeseburgers were very decent too. Star of the show, though, was the tuna tataki - a nicely balanced small (but quite generous) plate and, in accordance with the fashion du jour, attractively florally enhanced.
The drinks selection was inviting, and quite reasonably priced too. For lunch, a pint of Brooklyn - what else, round here? - made a very good accompaniment.

Another slice of Americana is set to hit our shores in the form of US pizza chain, Project Pie. And where has this company chosen to plant its first European restaurant? Why Dundee of course! But Project Pie isnâ€™t stopping there, Scottish domination is on the agenda with five more sites planned over the next [â€¦]

The group, which also has emerging pizza powerhouse Franco Manco in its armoury, has been defying a tricky and widespread downturn in the casual dining sector, joining the likes of Dishoom and Rosaâ€™s Thai in pursuing expansion despite a troubled market.
will launch in Bridgemasterâ€™s House, Propel first reported, and follows two other new restaurants in Covent Garden this year.

This new restaurant and private memberâ€™s bar has been likened to â€œa gothic Claridgesâ€. But aside from a quirky line in animal skulls (which make up a chandelier, wall lights, and just sit around on the bar), its airy dÃ©cor fits firmly into the vaguely Manhattanite style thatâ€™s so familiar in the area. With its dark wood floors, steel pillars, and chocolate brown just about everything else, itâ€™s classic Shoreditch.

On my visit, the jovial barman was sporting a frilled â€œbuccaneerâ€ shirt. With his flowing locks, he looked a bit like a survivor from an early â€™80s heavy metal band and added some much-needed raffish charm to what at lunch is still a pretty dead scene. At night-time, he told me, things are becoming much more happening (and on cue as he said this, someone poked their head round the door to nab a table for twelve at 9pm).

Here we go once again. This month, the famous Ms Marmite Lover finally enters the fray, Lizzie Mabbot dethrones Chris Pople to go top and the highest climber is The Graphic Foodie to number 13, up by 12. Congratulations to all. Isnâ€™t it more exciting watching the list change leaders now that the all powerful WOM (it is still all powerful, and no list is going to change that right?) has vacated the top spot?

If a success, this 400-seat Mayfair newcomer could quite possibly end up biggest-grossing restaurant in London. Comprising large dining rooms both Italian and Asian and an enormous basement bar, itâ€™s roughly a third bigger than the D&D (â€˜Conranâ€™) groupâ€™s Quaglinoâ€™s or Ramsayâ€™s Bread Street, which are as big as quality London restaurants currently get.

The Conran comparison is particularly apposite, as Arkady Novikov is the Sir Terence Conran of Moscow, just much bigger. Claiming 50 restaurants in the Russian capital, his empire is at least twice the size of D&Dâ€™s. Thatâ€™s the sort of success that buys you toys such as Gianni Versaceâ€™s former house on Lake Como, as well as a handy townhouse in Knightsbridge.

The new restaurant occupies a site where others have tried and failed, so the obvious question is: is Mayfair going to be Mr Novikovâ€™s Waterloo? Initial impressions are indeed that the Italian restaurant feels like a bit of a ballroom â€“ how is that going to work in a city where upmarket Italians are invariably on an intimate scale? The panelled basement bar, however, is a great space, which we suspect will become a popular rendezvous; letâ€™s hope it doesnâ€™t end up ALL Russians and their striking nieces.

But our mission that day was to check out the on-your-way-in Asian restaurant. With its unadorned dark wood tables, and the glazed-in kitchen visible in the distance, it has a somewhat Identikit quality about it â€“ not unpleasant, but not a particular attraction in its own right either. Pretty much ideal, then, for the sort of informal business lunching which had already drawn quite a good crowd by the time of our early-days visit.

The real surprise, however, was the food â€“ which was, with one exception, consistently impressive. The quality comes as more a shock, because a pan-Asian menu â€“ by definition â€“ lacks any sort of coherency. From a reviewing point of view, that makes it curiously easy, as you just have to order one of everything â€“ sushi, skewers, dim sum, barbecue. All of the above were just very good, with the surprise highlight being a dish of truffled duck. The only dish that didnâ€™t quite live up to its price tag (Â£45!) was some tempura lobster â€“ not bad, just not really worth the expense. Otherwise, the prices seemed pretty reasonable. For Mayfair.

Claiming to be Londonâ€™s most eco-friendly restaurant, a pioneering, if obscurely located, Shoreditch brasserie with a nice atmosphere and pleasant, informed service; on our visit, though, the cooking was in undoubted need of tightening up.

The team behind Acorn House, and now this Shoreditch newcomer, have a mission, and a laudable one too. They aim to demonstrate that restaurants donâ€™t have to be the energy guzzling monsters too many of them are (and also that eco-sensitivity is not inimical to creating restaurants which will keep the punters coming back).

Either theyâ€™re mad, or theyâ€™re on to something.  Tending to support the former view, the place was empty on our Monday lunchtime visit. Tending to support the latter, it had apparently been full for much of the weekend. Either way, we learnt on our visit that a site for venture number three has already been identified.

In a grungy bit of Shoreditch, it must be credit to the power of the press (though early reviews have been mixed) that this place ever has any customers at all. The idea of surfing the Zeitgeist obviously appeals, in this part of town at least.

So what do these surfers find? A harmonious modern bistro, nicely lit and comfortable, with linen napkins but no tablecloths. A canal-view too, of sorts. A friendly place, where everyone is very pleased to be involved in creating a better world. Itâ€™s even, ÃƒÂ  la Fifteen, something of a training-restaurant too.

With all these other virtues, it would perhaps be a surprise if the food were particularly remarkable, and we would have to record that ours was not. Nothing was unpleasant, but many dishes had a slight feeling of something missing. Bread was unremarkable. Starters of soups and antipasti didnâ€™t quite make the grade.  A risotto wasnâ€™t quite right, and a dish of lamb and roast potatoes lacked taste. Towards the end, however, things picked up. A foodie guest raved about the ice cream, and the chocolate tart with it really did melt (in the very best way), and the espresso was excellent.
This is, we suspect, a place which really shines at brunch, in which, we understand, they are already doing very good business.

will return for the fourth year in a row to raise money for the restaurant industryâ€™s charity of choice, Action Against Hunger. This time around the event will be held at the new Street Feast venue Hawker House in Canada Water where top chefs will cook up street food style dishes.

â€œIt sounds simple, almost dull, but it so, so wasnâ€™tâ€ â€“ service has a â€œsaucy twinkleâ€ and the whole experience was â€œknowingly, almost comically instagrammableâ€. In fact, he hails it as â€œright up thereâ€ with the â€œburning stars in the new London restaurant firmamentâ€. (26/30)
restaurant criticâ€ visited The River Cafe in order to establish â€œa bedrock for my future forays into Londonâ€™s freshest culinary venturesâ€. Whatever the excuse, he

investigates the â€œextravagantly namedâ€ Xiâ€™an Biang Biang Noodles in Spitalfields, part of the â€œglorious flowering in the variety of Chinese food available in Britainâ€™s citiesâ€ as a result of the opening up of China.

This â€œnoisy, fighty foodâ€ is served in a â€œbig, brightly lit canteenâ€ thatâ€™s perfect for crowds or solo diners like him (â€œI always think better of restaurants where people feel comfortable eating alone.â€).
