Xiâ€™an Biang Biang is â€œa utilitarian, great value enterprise posited on high-volume tradeâ€ with â€œuncompromising punchâ€ in the cooking. Jay had been asked to consult on the future of Chinese restaurants in London, and was reassured by his visit here.

recommends a visit to Loughborough pub The Hammer & Pincers for the grazing menu â€“ itself recommended to him by a reader . visited Gjelina, in Californiaâ€™s Venice Beach, California: â€œitâ€™s muscular dude-food meets healthy eating, with an Italian accentâ€.

Comfortably decorated in style imitating the coffee bars of the â€˜swinging Sixtiesâ€™, this Little India basement restaurant offers food thatâ€™s perfectly acceptable, but not obviously better than at many neighbouring establishments.

This is a smart and professionally turned out basement operation, whose rather late-60s orange-themed dÃ©cor nods elegantly to the period when these streets to the west of Euston station first became known for inexpensive Indian restaurants (especially of the veggie variety). Staff were pleasant too, and trying hard. Prices are not demanding.

The food, however, consistently failed to excite. And not just on the palate. Our lunch companion was one of those obsessives who photographs dishes, and we particularly couldnâ€™t help noting that our array of starters â€“ veggie fritters, and a soft shell crab â€“ made a totally unrelieved symphony in brown. This is the second of two Continental-style steak-houses to open in Marylebone in recent months. Both offer essentially the same fixed menu â€“ salad, steak â€˜nâ€™ chips â€“ and both make a big deal of their respective secret sauces. The first to open (Relais de Venise) was praised in this column, but has subsequently been slated by most other critics. If popularity is anything to go by, however, the punters are with us.

Part of de Veniseâ€™s success is no doubt due to the fact that it is an authentic â€“ and so far one-off â€“ replica of the Parisian original, and comes complete with a good dose of joie de vivre. This newcomer, however â€“ an offshoot of an outfit from Geneva, and with outlets in Lisbon and Dubai â€“ just seems like an authentic replica of uninspired restaurants everywhere. If they didnâ€™t just inherit the interior here, the person who designed it â€“ in a style 20 years out of date â€“ should be shot.

The food does little to raise the spirits. The salad â€“ marginally better than at de Venise â€“ lost its advantage by being served up with dull bread. Steak/frites were a pretty much total disappointment. It does not help that your dinner plate arrives with the chips already on board â€“ a school-diners style of service that has no place in even the humblest bistro. That special sauce â€“ which had separated â€“ seemed to add little to a pretty pallid bit of beef. If you try this place, weâ€™d certainly recommend a good dose of Dijon to spice it up. A crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e was pleasant enough, but we left our coffee undrunk.

So you just sit there quietly, fuming rather, until a sprinkling of the diners with Holy Water signifies that itâ€™s all over. After nearly a quarter of a century in this business, itâ€™s nice to know that restaurant reviewing can still harbour the occasional surprise.

The surprise is that such a standardised formula seems to â€˜workâ€™. Indeed, this particular cosy restaurant  â€“ perhaps helped by contrast to the bombast of neighbouring Candy Towers â€“ succeeds in feeling quite a haven. For some reason, new-wave Old English food is something you normally only find in pubs. There is of course a famous exception â€“ the founder of the movement, St John of Smithfield. But the vast majority of St Johnâ€™s imitators and inspirees are pubs, or dining rooms attached to pubs.

The logic of this (or lack of it) may have struck the owners of this newcomer â€“ opposite Covent Gardenâ€™s Masonic Temple â€“ many of whom also backed the Anchor & Hope, the most prominent gastropub of recent years. You never quite know what to expect at a Gordon Ramsay establishment. Within a mile or so of each other, you can have places which are very good (PÃ©trus, say), and places which are mediocre (Foxtrot Oscar). Itâ€™s one of the mysteries of the celebrity-chefdom lark that these famous â€˜brandsâ€™ have transcended the need to offer any particular level of quality or consistency. Arenâ€™t brands supposed to have brand values?

If youâ€™re looking for similarities with Bread Street, though, glance at the menu. The first thing you notice is that simplicity is not the order of the day, in the sense that many dishes need a sentence to describe them, rather than a phrase. The second thing you notice is that even when dishes sound as if you could do this at home, they come with impressive prices. A rib-eye steak, for example, is Â£34, Mutton pie Â£21. Our simple lunch, for one, making economical choices for each of three courses, with a glass of wine and an espresso, came to Â£55.

The food is not bad. Bread rolls have good taste and texture. A tuna tartare was nicely piquant. The â€˜cuissonâ€™ of Â the sea bream (â€œwith smoked aubergine, savoy cabbage, Castelluccio lentils and roast pumpkinâ€) was well enough judged, but finishing the dish was ultimately a bit of a chore. Perhaps a bit of crunch somewhere would not have gone amiss. The pear tart â€“ the pudding most strongly recommended â€“ was entirely as described, with no particular refinement or point of difference from a competent deli, and coffee likewise. The dishes came and went quickly: this is not really food to linger over.

is back eating Chinese food, this time in the presence of an expert, a lady he met at Kaki a few weeks ago, who has given him a list of the six best Chinese restuarants she goes to in London â€“ obviously he then claims these as his own, instantly doubling his three reviews per week.

was actually in new territory this week, at a place that none of the other nationals have covered yet. Bath might not exactly be out of his comfort zone, but itâ€™s an impressive effort all the same.

The Beckford Bottle Shopâ€™s new Bath sibling is a wine merchant with a restaurant â€œserving up â€˜small platesâ€™, as well as a â€˜curated selectionâ€™ of British cheese and charcuterieâ€. While he mocked it as being â€œachingly on-trendâ€ and a little bit Hackney, TPB loved it.

And the food? â€œThe menuâ€™s so beguiling that we order the whole damned lot. And not a dish disappoints.â€
â€œYoung head chef Harry Russellâ€ is â€œa talent to watchâ€: his food is â€œsimple, straightforward, and joyously confidentâ€ â€œBath has a new star. Get there, before everyone else does.â€

A brilliant marketing wheeze â€“ all possible fresh produce is sourced from the immediate environs of the capital â€“ has already assured many column inches of coverage for this new restaurant in a former pub.

As it turns out, the only thing wrong with this place is the food. Wandsworth-baked bread, brought immediately, was fine â€“ white, chewy and, in a good way, very English. But who in their right mind would serve olive oil with bread like that? It made no sense. Neither, really, did Chesham goatâ€™s cheese nettles  pirogi, which tasted as unappetising as they looked; a few greasy breadcrumbs on top did not help. A Canvey Dover sole was plated up complete with head, skin and roe. The flesh had admittedly been grilled to perfection, but the accompanying spinach verged on inedible. A baked cheesecake was a great wodge of a thing, with a claggy base, and accompanied by an ungainly dollop of rhubarb jam. After this multiple assault, only a strong post-prandial filter coffee stopped me feeling slightly queasy.

So, as youâ€™ll gather, I canâ€™t really recommend this brave new venture, which is a shame. But chefs who build their PR on the metropolitan associations of their food need to ensure that it is not dished up in a style which verges on agricultural.
A true neighbourhood restaurant, hidden away near the Thames in Battersea, offering simple Gallic fare; we found the cuisine generous, but rather lacking in finesse.

When you see menu of this notably unpretentious all-day joint, which opened up near the Battersea riverside early in 2007, you may feel that you have stumbled into some sort of Francophile heaven. This double-page job â€“ printed up freshly every day â€“ offers dishes ranging from pancakes and croques-messieurs to quite ambitious plats du jour â€“ perfect, it seems, for everything from lunch with the kids to an informal romantic dinner (if you avoid the football evenings, that is). There is an excellent range of French wines (and other drinks) too, all at reasonable prices.

Sadly, on our visit, the food just did not live up to the promise. Bread set a upbeat note, and a reasonably-priced kidsâ€™ pasta special was also good, but there were just too many duds. Thatâ€™s not to say that thereâ€™s any want of generosity â€“ if anything, portions are too big â€“ but a seafood chowder was impossibly salty, and both a venison plat du jour and a floating island would have benefited from being half the size and twice as subtle. Coffee was also indifferent.
Run by the eponymous Otto, a straight-down-the-line Gallic restaurant, offering classic cooking of good quality, in an attractive and characterful Bloomsbury setting.

The idea that a restaurant is an extension of the personality, even the home, of its proprietor is common in France. Witness the number of restaurants called â€˜Chezâ€™ quelquâ€™un. But you see it surprisingly rarely here. In London, the aim of mid-market restaurants often seems to be de-personalised good taste, rather than any expression of character, or still less of personality.

So we noticed when Otto (for it was he) greeted us as we entered this Bloomsbury restaurant, and was there as we left, too â€“ discussing the menu for that evening with one of his staff. We also noticed that the interior, in a light and airy period room in Bloomsbury, is decked out with that quirky, slightly domestic, taste that the French often apply to restaurants, but which an Englishman would somehow find embarrassing.

As at so many French restaurants, the aim is to do classic dishes well rather than to aim for any particular novelty. Thus our lunch menu for two comprised terrine and scallops, steak and seabass. Nothing to startle, then, but it was striking that everything â€“ from the decent crispy baguette (for once) to the coffee â€“ was done consistently well, and sometimes very well indeed.

For a lunchtime discussion in an unhurried and restful setting, we doubt that â€“ anywhere in the centre of our great city â€“ you could have done very much better than we did on on the day of our visit. And, by night, we fancy this must be quite an old-fashioned-romantic place too.

has â€œstumbled across the living definition of the word â€œpreciousâ€: a seafood restaurant, a fishmonger and a champagne bar in â€” where else? â€” Chelseaâ€.

â€œAt times it feels as if there are two kitchens back there. Cross your fingers and hope you get food prepared by the good one.â€ Will you â€œcoo and purrâ€ over your dish, or will it leave you with â€œaching eyeballs from all the rollingâ€?

Or perhaps they just propose to redecorate monthly? When our lunch for two effortlessly breaching the Â£100 barrier, the prices would certainly seem to allow for such an extravagance.

(and her family) stopped off for a meal at the year-old Mara. Itâ€™s an unlikely venue for an impromptu wake â€“ itâ€™s â€œofficially a takeaway, you canâ€™t make bookings and there isnâ€™t a toiletâ€. But the food made up for that.

this week. No, not a review that gets something other than four stars, but a Mexican restaurant weâ€™d previously not heard about (even though itâ€™s been around since 2016, starting â€œas so many places doâ€, as a food truck), in Woking, of all places.

reported on the demise of Manchesterâ€™s Curry Mile â€“ thereâ€™s now just eight restaurants left from a high of 50 in the 1990s. They have been replaced â€“ and improved upon â€“ but places like
On the former Chelsea site of Aubergine, a welcoming and elegantly-styled new Italian restaurant; the cooking, though, is tame.

Honey, we forgot the food! Are we imagining it, or is there a bit of a spate of restaurant at the moment which are very nice in every wayâ€™ except that the food is entirely unremarkable? The new Italian restaurant on the Chelsea site that was formerly called Aubergine (same ownership), would appear to be a classic example.

Concerns that the food might not live up, however, started right at the beginning. We have a theory â€“ doubtless weâ€™ve shared it with you before if you read our reviews with any regularity â€“ that you can usually tell everything you need to know about a restaurant from its bread. This was a classic example â€“ the basket of brown and white breads which arrived was undistinguished in both taste and texture, and owed nothing obvious to Italy.

The meal which followed was not bad, but it was, pretty much all of a piece with the bread â€“ not bad or unpleasant, but safe, standard and somewhat uninspired. The best dish was a pannacotta that was almost too generous. But it was too late by then. The feeling that this is a restaurant where theyâ€™d forgotten about the food was, by that point, inescapable.

Modestly revamped, this lake-view Barbican restaurant offers an interesting menu in a room still rather redolent of the â€™70s; while the cooking is of good quality, the bravely English menu perhaps lacks the general appeal that youâ€™d expect for the dining facility of a cultural centre.

First problem, however, was that we couldnâ€™t actually see any obvious physical changes. We were therefore very grateful to our helpful and engaging waiter for pointing out that the carpet had changed colour, and that there was now a new dining bar where solo diners can eat watching the goings-on by the lake. For a place that had just been â€˜relaunchedâ€™, though, weâ€™d have to say the overall impression was one of continuity (and, letâ€™s be frank, just a little bit dreary â€“ these â€™70s spaces take quite a lot of livening up). It didnâ€™t help that the place, admittedly in the first week of its new guise, was pretty much empty for lunch.

The result of all this Englishness, can, in short, be a menu which lacks â€˜easyâ€™ appeal: there was nothing on the menu that our (professional-diner) lunching companion really wanted. Thatâ€™s not to denigrate the aim, which is a worthy one, but we suspect that this whole English thing â€“ it its extreme form â€“ may be a bit of a fad, and that weâ€™ll shortly all go back to the sort of Anglo-French stuff thatâ€™s done quite nicely for the last century or so (if, perhaps, with more English dishes, and a bit more emphasis on local provenance). Thatâ€™s not to criticise the realisation or presentation of the food  we tried, though, which was thoroughly good, if not, of itself, a sufficient reason to seek the place out.

And thereâ€™s the rub. We do see getting the punters in as a bit of an issue here, and we do wonder if the absence of a keenly-priced set lunch and pre-theatre menu isnâ€™t just a little bit barmy. This is quite a big restaurant, and â€“ particularly with its slightly â€˜acquired-tasteâ€™ menu â€“ itâ€™s difficult to see how theyâ€™re really going to build the custom up any other way.

The former Balham Bar & Grill, modestly revamped, and now owned by Sam Harrison of Samâ€™s Brasserie (W4) fame; it remains a friendly and stylish spot, but the food is still rather an incidental attraction.

Nick Jones is one of the most successful club-proprietors of our day, and his Soho Houses â€“ recently acquired by Scotts-proprietor Richard Caring â€“ have become default media glitterati boltholes in both London and New York. Heâ€™s no slouch as a restaurateur either, and has brought a trendy vibe to establishments such as Cecconiâ€™s in Mayfair. Even he, though, was defeated by Balham. Well, no, thatâ€™s not really true. Having been part of the early-wave operators that made Balham the bijou destination it is today, he decided last year that the sarf London suburb establishment no longer really fitted with his NyLon portfolio. The solution was to job the place on to Sam Harrison. The latter is, of course, the Sam of eponymous Chiswick brasserie fame, and heâ€™s now put the other half of his name over the door in Balham.

Given the fact that Harrisonâ€™s is, spiritually speaking, the son of two trendy(ish) local destinations where the food is rather a secondary attraction, the new establishment is exactly what you would expect. A Saturday brunchtime visit found quite a buzzy place (not attracting a particularly beautiful crowd, it would have to be said) with pleasant (but sometimes slow) service and food which was very much a supporting attraction. Burger and chips seemed to be the local dish of choice â€“ ours was in no way remarkable, and the other dishes were broadly in keeping.
Children are well looked after, but donâ€™t dominate, making this a real all-the-family destination. We still left, though, regretting that the food was not that little bit better.

Mrs Harden was not happy. Like her sister-in-law (also Mrs Harden) she knows by now that restaurant critics donâ€™t just spend their lives checking out the latest Knightsbridge hotspots. But trekking to Brixton on a cold and windy night? Well, really.

The many clouds overhanging our visit darkened further when the restaurant didnâ€™t seem to be at the appointed address. Mercifully it didnâ€™t take too long to find the entry â€“ on Branscome Road â€“ even though it is only marked, speakeasy-style, by an Entryphone.

The buzzer whirred, and the door opened onto a winding staircase. Up we go to find a small bar, and then up again to a tiny dining room with a Lilliputian real fire. The room, surprisingly, has a view, of which the distant focal point is an illuminated building of some grandeur. â€˜It looks like Parliament, but isnâ€™tâ€™Â, said the charming French waitress. Actually, it is.

The menu is Gallic, and, given the small scale of the operation, sensibly short: three choices per course, plus the odd â€˜specialâ€™. Everything is simply but nicely presented. A small and tightly-packed East End dining room, entered via an art gallery, where Maria Elia (who has a bit of a name, from her time at the Delfina Studio CafÃ©) cooks up food of proper restaurant quality.

Londonâ€™s galleries and museums tend to offer little of interest on the food front. Part of the problem is that, big and institutional bodies as they are, they tend to appoint big, joyless catering companies to do the job for them.

All credit, then, to the relaunched Whitechapel Gallery, which has taken an independent approach to its in-house restaurant. The result is an establishment which doesnâ€™t feel at all institutional. It may be symbolic that, though you enter through the gallery entrance, the restaurant overlooks a busy (and not especially attractive) streetscape, which tends to suggest that this is a â€˜realâ€™ restaurant that just happens to be attached to an art gallery. (Perhaps this really is the â€œace cafe with a museum attachedâ€ of which the V&A once famously boasted.)

On our early-days visit, the place was already busy for lunch, and deservedly so. Perhaps it helps that the chef knows a bit about cooking in a cultural environment. Whatever the reason, the food was much better than one might expect.

And pretty too. Dishes here are carefully plated, and nicely balanced. A ham hock terrine, for example, comes elegantly laid out, and accompanied by nicely-timed quailâ€™s eggs and still-warm asparagus. Bream comes similarly well presented, with mash and beetroot. Even the few elements involved in a dish of good treacle tart and crÃ¨me fraÃƒÂ®che are carefully composed. Bread and coffee are well above average.

There are niggles. Space is tight. Prices are just a touch higher than you might hope. Bread does not come gratis. Service rather comes and goes. But all these are details. This is a gallery restaurant seemingly run as a restaurant, rather than as an  afterthought. Surely this is an idea that might just â€“ finally â€“ catch on?

A vehicle for a chef of undoubted talent, this ostentatious Mayfair â€˜brasserieâ€™ offers perfectly acceptable food and service but on our early-days visit any sort of excitement was signally lacking.

Other reviewers have tended, in not invariably, to find main courses the highlight of the cooking here, and a dish such as duckling ÃƒÂ  lâ€™orange with endives was notably elegantly plated and tasty too, if perhaps rather â€“ like the whole concept â€“ lacking heart. Puddings, on the other hand, have not been seen as a strong point, but we enjoyed our rum baba, and the coffee was fine, if nothing remarkable.

From the upper deck of our City AM limousine, we saw an impressive place weâ€™d not previously noticed. Once a grand banking hall, it looked â€“ with its fancy lighting, smartly-dressed tables and a menu outside â€“ for all the world like the sort of place readers ought to know about.

When we actually perused the menu, however, we began to understand the thin house. Its style (we subsequently learnt) is â€˜Modern European comfort foodâ€™Â, which seems to mean that it was designed by a committee with at least one oriental member. So it seemed rude not to try out the sushi and sashimi starter. This foray into multi-culturalism was not a success, however as the tempura salmon nori roll â€“ if thankfully only part of the dish â€“ was every bit as horrid as it sounded.

The most striking thing about the meal was a burger. Not just any old burger you understand, but a burger with no fewer than five enormous onion rings piled on top of it, four and a half of which return to the kitchen uneaten. The chips werenâ€™t much cop either. The burger itself, however, was flavoursome and accurately cooked. Puddings are quite decent too, and coffee, for once, was thoughtfully served with hot milk. Itâ€™s not as if thereâ€™s no hope, here.
On leaving, we caught sight of the DJâ€™s decks, which suggest that â€“ by night â€“ this place lives up to its name. With a few tweaks, though, it could be useful by day too.

Old Spitalfields Market â€“ one of east Londonâ€™s most iconic and treasured sites â€“ will relaunch its food offering on 13 October with a whole host of street food vendors. The all-star line-up of traders known as â€œThe Kitchensâ€, opens on 13 October, and will modernise the market floor. The newly designed stalls will house 10 of the hottest names in Londonâ€™s street food scene, including:

, a new offering from Hugh Thorn and Luke Clarkson will explore the diverse flavours throughout Asia and the sub-continent. , cult street food traders with a loyal following, John Li and Yee Li have spent three years perfecting their dumpling recipes. Their specialty is outstanding Shengjianbao dumplings but theyâ€™ll also be showcasing home-made dan dan noodles, a Chinese street food classic.

, one of the winners of at the 2017 Young British Foodie awards, Terri Mercieca has already gathered a cult following for her creative range of ice cream sandwiches & desserts. , these Shoreditch natives will serve up a range of Nordic inspired dishes with a strong focus on preservation. , a new offering from the team behind Dalston Japanese restaurant and music venue Brilliant Corners. , an east London pop-up restaurant serving seasonal fresh pasta dishes such as amatriciana and radicchio, gorgonzola tortelloni and breakfast brioche buns with guanciale. They will also offer authentic Italian products such as burrata, cheeses and cured meats.

, a regular feature in â€˜top street foodâ€™ lists, Yum Bun will bring their fluffy pockets of flavour to Old Spitalfields market and launch a new dish â€“ a Spiced fried chicken, salted celery slaw and Szechuan Mayo bun.

A new line-up of traders representing small, independent and local businesses will join the community over the course of the next six months. The completed market will feature in excess of 100 market traders and a new events programme, all to be unveiled in spring 2018. Eventually supporting a community of 114 traders across the Kitchens, food and retail stalls, the remodelled Old Spitalfields Market aims to give small and independent operators a much-needed platform to showcase their brands.

ate dishes that were â€œreminiscent of something an antihero in a Bret Easton Ellis novel would orderâ€ at Gazelle, a â€œvery, very cool new restaurantâ€ in Mayfair â€œwhere the vibe is experimental and gastronomically challengingâ€.

review took her to Native, recently moved from Covent Garden to a bigger and batter Southwark site. assures us that London does need another piri piri chicken place â€“ specifically Caso do Frango, which he called â€œdelightfulâ€. Itâ€™s a â€œhuge, airy space hard by Borough Marketâ€ thatâ€™s Â â€œeffortless shabby chicâ€ and has â€œan inside-out feelâ€.

plumped for this Mayfair Italian (imported from Milan) over bleeding vegan burgers, crazy golf, caviar and Japanese-Italian fusion (all genuine recent openings in the Big Smoke).

magazine) was a little startled at the bill for 6 people at Casa Cruz, a three-year-old restaurant in Notting Hill (â€œwhere all the rich foreign weirdos who live round there go for dinner most nightsâ€). The dining room â€“ which felt rather like a better proportioned version of St Alban â€“ seemed a bit odd initially, as we were the first luncher to arrive, but as the place filled up, which it largely did, it â€˜workedâ€™ surprisingly well.

On the Belgravia/Pimlico fringe, the former Ebury has been relaunched as a good-all-round bar/restaurant, offering food of no particular ambition, but realised with solid consistency.

Zakudia, as you will know, is a Zambian word, meaning the enjoyment of food and drink. Itâ€™s also the name of this bar by Southwark Bridge, which is of note as the only non-chain outlet in a string of places to have opened over the last couple of years around Shakespeareâ€™s Globe.

Stairs lead up from an office-like foyer to the first-floor bar. Itâ€™s a long, thin, low-ceilinged space, saved from feeling like a corporate conference chamber by a fabulous Thames panorama: from Tate Modern, past St Paulâ€™s to Southwark Bridge itself.

At the arrival of the cocktail list and menu, my heart sank. While the former was a lavish full-colour production full of sexily-named enticements to kill off the rest of the day, the latter was a tatty photocopied sheet, with a selection â€“ notwithstanding the odd nod to Africa â€“ almost exclusively composed of standard bar and grazing fodder. A thirst-quencher arrived in the form of one of their fresh-fruit blends, which delivered a refreshing kick. The wine list being practically non-existent I opted for one of the two beers â€“ a Finnish Lapin Kulta â€“ whose distinguishing feature seemed to be a total lack of taste.

The arrival of my bread â€“ a huge plate with dips â€“ reinforced the notion that the grub here is just to soak up the brews. That said, it was tasty enough. Perfectly OK fishcakes and chips, for example, suggest that the food â€“ if not the main thing â€“ â€œdoes the jobâ€, and in generous portions to boot.

With its laid-back service and attractive-going-on-neutral modern decor thereâ€™s certainly nothing earth-shattering about Zakudia. With its fab views, easygoing charm and quality cocktails, though, this is a useful place to know about on the ever more-trendy South Bank strip.

was back in London this week after reviewing several remarkably low-priced restaurants across the UK. Scully is in direct contrast to those places â€“ â€œthe only way you can get out of there for less than Â£100 at dinner is by not doing it properlyâ€.

A plain Smithfield establishment on the former Rudland & Stubbs (RIP) site, bearing the name of a former Caprice group executive chef; our early-days sampling of the meat-heavy English menu showed signs of promise, but the performance overall struck us as complacent.

OK. So, for years, youâ€™ve been a chef of some eminence (if perhaps not quite a household name), but always cooking for other people (the Caprice group). Youâ€™ve pumped out a cookbook a year in recent times, and write a newspaper column. Youâ€™ve become something of a hero of the English culinary renaissance. And you finally decide itâ€™s time to go it alone. The moment has come to launch an establishment with your own name above the door.

This single fact tells you almost everything you need to know about the priorities of the modern chef/media persona. It doesnâ€™t matter that youâ€™re on the very brink of opening your first solo restaurant, bearing your very own name â€“ whatâ€™s most important is to be off hob-nobbing with other foodie luminaries.

Now, if Mr Hixâ€™s Smithfield restaurant had actually been ready to open, firing on all cylinders, on the appointed day, such commentary would be irrelevant. But, even towards the end of the first week, its performance was still very ragged indeed. The table layout was still being tinkered with, service was still very slow (and notably disjointed), and deliveries (such as that all-important ironing board) were still being received through the front door.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
A no-nonsense English bistro, near Camden Town tube; a friendly sort of place, it offers plain cooking - in a style which, until recently, might have been called domestic - at reasonable prices.

So what are the attractions? Well, friendly staff with a can-do attitude make up one part of the package. And the lofty and spacious interior is smartly decked out too, if in the slightly bland sort of way that says this hopes to be a chain one day. The food is rather in keeping with the dÃ©cor, but the pizzas and pastas were generally reasonably satisfying.

So â€˜justâ€™ a goodish all-rounder, then. But a reasonably priced one too, in an area that is rather lacking in such things at the moment. (Thereâ€™s no PizzaExpress, for example, within easy walking distance.)
We keep reading that this much-lauded Soho newcomer â€“ fronted by Russell Norman, once a bigwig at the Caprice group â€“ is some sort of Venetian snack bar (or, to impress you with our research,
). Has anyone looked at it? This is a New York restaurant, pure and simple. Or, more specifically, a Downtown restaurant.

The only wonder is that itâ€™s taken so long for this particular style of deconstructed chic to make the jump from SoHo to Soho: Polpo immediately reminded us a of a particular SoHo-fringe operation, Peasant, which opened as long ago as 2000. Mr Norman readily admits such restaurants (if not that specific one) have provided just as much inspiration for him as anything in La Serenissima, and will even tell you the name of the particular firm of Big Apple architects whose work has inspired him: Avroko.

It isnâ€™t just the styling, of course (not generally commented on in the very positive early-days reviews elsewhere) which is responsible for the crush, but also the much-complimented food. Not that the cuisine is in any way astonishing, itâ€™s just that it is generally very well done, and amazingly, well,

. The cicheti (Italian tapas) are very tasty, as well as remarkably economical. The highlight for us (lunching in the singular) was a delicious pile of green tapenade on a piece of toasted bread, but arancini (rice balls) also satisfied. To follow, fegato alla Veneziana, a small but very adequate dish for around Â£6, was well complemented by a plate of zucchini dressed with olive oil. Add a plate of roast autumn fruits (the best dish, dressed with a sprinkle of crumble), and youâ€™ve still, with modest wine, had a very pleasant lunch for Â£25. Which may be another reason the place is already humming.

The obvious problem is that, with value like this, either prices will rise or tables will be impossible to get. Or both. So how long till the successor restaurant? As youâ€™ve probably gathered, this is not the sort of place where a known reviewer is likely to be able to maintain any sort of anonymity, so we can tell you what Mr Norman told us â€“ start looking out for number two some time next year.
Itâ€™s stressful choosing a restaurant for friends. If you write about restaurants for a living, then mates are not generally especially forgiving when you take them somewhere thatâ€™s rubbish.

Gowtham Karingi has cooked at Veeraswaamy and Zaika, and his food avoids the westernised feeling of some â€˜nouvelle Indianâ€™ cuisine. Iâ€™ll spare you the blurb about the ayurvedic principles behind Agni (which means â€˜fierce determinationâ€™). Suffice it to say, for intelligent, flavour-packed cuisine, this is the real thing.

The menu combines brilliant realisations of old favourites with more exciting evolved dishes. Starters included some excellent chaat and delicious fried squid.  Among the main dishes, the stand-outs were Fish Balchao â€“ where tilapia fish had been cooked in a beautifully-spiced sauce â€“ and a deeply intense lamb curry (itâ€™s Roghan Josh Jim, but not as we know it). Unusually for any kind of Indian restaurant, the best was kept till last with a magnificent finale of red chilli ice cream.

If the proof of the pudding is in the eating though, perhaps the true success of the evening was that my friends were so delighted they picked up the bill. At least Iâ€™d chosen somewhere for them with bargain prices.

A Kingâ€™s Road pub, relaunched â€“ and much tarted-up â€“ by the Martin brothers (of Gun etc fame); the food can be pretty good, but we do wonder if â€“ as an eating place â€“ the formula quite â€˜worksâ€™.

, on the Isle of Dogs, back in 2004, Tom and Ed Martin have become leading lights in Londonâ€™s gastropub/English bistro scene. (It seems to us that this is a distinction thatâ€™s becoming pretty much irrelevant: many pubs are now really informal restaurants, and some restaurants are now adopting â€˜gastropubâ€™ style. What, apart from architecture, is the meaningful distinction between the two?)

The menu is more in keeping with the dÃ©cor than the service.  Though shorter than the one at the frankly brasserie-like Botanist, just up the road, itâ€™s not so different in style, which is to say it is not notably pubby at all. Our meal for one included some good and interesting bread, an elegant pea soup, a pretty good cheesecake and a decent espresso. The only dull moment was a rather salty chicken pie, with an unimpressive hat, which came with a slick of not especially appealing mash.

Despite food thatâ€™s â€“ on balance â€“ pretty good, however, we do have some questions whether, in a part of town which does not want for â€˜properâ€™ restaurants,  this non-pubby pub really quite works as a concept. The boysâ€™ success to date, however, suggests it probably will.

And on the way, you pass this chic-looking new Japanese. Huge picture windows give the ground floor (thereâ€™s also a basement) a fine view of the canal, while the very airy interior is a stylish medley of slate, dark-stained timber, and green velvet drapes. If I hadnâ€™t known that it was the creation of a Russian restaurant group, I would have thought that it was a third opening by Rainer Becker of Roka and Zuma fame.

The fashionable Japanese menu is reminiscent of Rokaâ€™s with its emphasis on skewers from the charcoal robata grill, alongside a wide selection of sushi and main dishes. I went for a catholic selection incorporating five kinds of skewer and some trendy sounding â€˜spicey red-eyeâ€™ and â€˜gardenâ€™ sushi â€” the former spiked with chilli pepper, the latter using ingredients like burdock. None of the items were disappointing, but equally all fell short of being inspirational.

Service was charming but a little keystone kops-ish (or whatever it is that Russians say for being disorganised and amateurish). Surely they can sort that out? Because if they can, the beautiful interior, picturesque setting and decent food are a strong incentive to venture a stroll in Paddington Waterside.

On the 33rd floor of the Shard, an ambitious Chinese restaurant that was still giving a slight impression of settling in on our visit; we had an enjoyable lunch, though, and prices are not unreasonable, considering.

It used to be easy. High-rise restaurants in London were few, small and expensive, and everyone knew they were primarily there to rip off tourists, birthday celebrants and romantics. Yet, as London reaches for the stars, such restaurants have suddenly become so numerous as to seem almost unremarkable. Take the lift to the 33rd floor of the Shard, for example, and you find a complex comprising not one but two Aqua-group restaurants (Aqua Shard, British in style, as well as Hutong), and also a brasserie-style operation (Oblix) run by Rainer Becker of Zuma fame â€“ the bars and dining rooms can accommodate hundreds of guests in total. (And thatâ€™s before a Shangri-La hotel opens in the same building at the end of the year.)

The landlords must have been cutting good deals, because space is used at these new establishments in a lavish way which those of us used to the West Endâ€™s cosy ways can find it difficult to adjust to. Indeed, these vast air-conditioned expanses often just feel rather dead. And how can the actual dining rooms compete with the views, anyway? On our daytime visit, none of the Shard restaurant interiors filled us with any great excitement. Of the three, however, we suspect that the dark and dimly-lit interior of Hutong â€“ the swankiest of the establishments â€“ is the one that would work best by night. By day, leaving the view out of the reckoning, we felt as if we were lunching in one of the more upmarket of Mr Disneyâ€™s resort-hotel dining rooms (and not an especially comfortable one either).

The dim sum menu â€“ not especially helpfully divided up, in the way youâ€™d find in Chinatown â€“ seemed a good place to try a range of tastes, but the affable waiter steered us to the pre-chosen steamed selection from the main menu. These came prettily colour coded, not something we can really recall before, but the differences of hue among the selection was more pronounced than the differences of taste â€“ in every other way they hit the spot, though, and they certainly delivered quite a chilli kick.

Write a quick review now using our restaurant diary service. That way it might catch our attention. Next survey, you can transfer your diary entry into our survey system. Everyone who contributes 5 or more reviews in our survey will qualify for a free guide.
For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
On the Belgravia/Pimlico fringe, the former Ebury has been relaunched as a good-all-round bar/restaurant, offering food of no particular ambition, but realised with solid consistency.

Its rather picniccyÂ, said the young Miss Harden. As good a word as youre going to find to describe the bright and effortfully informal mismatched dÃ©cor of this large, light and airy Pimlico bar/restaurant, on the site long known as the Ebury. (Those with longer memories may recall it was once a pub where the highlight was stripper nights. How areas change.)

The same adjective could also be applied to the cuisine. This is, they say, intended to be a female-friendly sort of establishment, and the menu is long on snack-style dishes, including salads. Thats by no means to say theyre all lo-cal - our chicken schnitzel and chips was very good on both counts, though the portions might not satisfy a true trencherman. Bread was very good too, and came in a nice variety, even if they do charge for it. Prepare yourself for a real sugar high, but the rhubarb roulade - again, no real economiser on the calories - was a real highlight of a visit in which none of three people found anything really to fault.

As the dishes weve mentioned suggest, its clear that this is a place whose pretensions might be characterised as wholesome rather than foodie and the friendly service is very much in keeping with the general tone. But whats wrong with the sort of establishment which, back in Mrs Thatchers day, we might have described as a wine bar with food? When everythings done well, nothing in our book.

In the heart of Mayfair, a very useful corner gastropub, open 365 days a year; sibling to the House (Islington) and Bull (Highgate), it offers similarly solid cooking, and â€“ in this part of town â€“ the prices demanded for it seem eminently reasonable!

Itâ€™s not just in Mayfair that there are still â€“ yes, still â€“ far too few decent places for an unpretentious, affordable meal. All credit then to this corner gastropub newcomer â€“ from the same stable as the House and the Bull â€“ which not only offers precisely that formula, but is promising to do it 365 days a year.

We stopped by a for a quick lunch in the ground floor bar (largely given over to tables). Itâ€™s had a bit of a makeover, but the most eye-catching thing about  the place â€“ some of whose windows have false bottle-glass â€“ is that it still feels as if it should be in a Surrey high street, rather than one of the priciest postcodes in the world. Perhaps thatâ€™s part of its charm. The crowd on the day of our visit was also less glitzy than such a location might suggest.

The editorial â€˜weâ€™ in this case comprised just one luncher, and we just had a quick lunch of haddock â€˜nâ€™ chips, treacle tart and coffee. Perhaps we were just lucky, but it really was just the job. The chips were particularly interesting. Fat chips can be horrible, but these were exemplarily moreish in both their taste and their crispy texture. The tart also rated mention, steering that difficult middle course between being heavy handedly rustic on the one hand and too poncey on the other. Incidentals such as bread (made, for once, on the premises) and coffee were also well up to scratch.
The only problem, we suspect, is that this thoroughly useful but quite small place â€“ open all day as well as all year â€“ is going to be far too popular at peak times.

A case-study in â€˜how not to do a restaurant openingâ€™ (and that was leaving aside the ultra-mean portions); the design of this City newcomer is great, but is the current environment going to be receptive to this ostentatious spin-off from a West End original that was never such a â€˜raveâ€™ in the first place?

Itâ€™s a question restaurant reviewers ask themselves (and each other) a lot. Our attitude can be summarised, â€˜if youâ€™re charging full prices, expect to be judged accordinglyâ€™Â. So we were a little nonplussed by the performance of this pricey City newcomer.

Not an accusation you could level, by the way, at the design. Perhaps stung by the comparisons its dusky West End forebear has drawn to Hakkasan, the style here â€“ and theyâ€™ve spent a packet on it â€“ avoids dark hues for a light colour scheme. A large shimmering bar dominates the space, which is cleverly subdivided into a cocktail area and a main dining area, saving the room from feeling like the box it basically is. Whoâ€™d have thought a few years ago that youâ€™d get a place like this somewhere as boring as Angel Court?
We had been warned at the time of booking that full restaurant service was not yet available. However, having checked out the bar menu, weâ€™d decided to press on regardless. More fool us.

Perched on plush white leather in the luxurious bar, it quickly became apparent to us that our rather beautiful waitress had no great command of English, or, indeed, any feeling at all for what she was serving. â€˜Cobraâ€™Â, she explained â€“ unwrapping for us an arcane mystery of the East â€“ â€˜is an Indian beerâ€™Â.

Donâ€™t blame her, though. Blame the powers that be, who â€“ in a top dollar joint like this â€“ should have given her a bit more basic training. They should also, while they were at it, have made sure that the coffee and credit card machines were working, and avoided the numerous interruptions by various members of staff updating us on their bungling progress in trying to rectify matters.

And the food? OK, this was the bar menu. Even allowing for this, portions are outrageously dinky. A Â£6.50 portion of asparagus, involved maybe two spears (or was it three?) pretentiously chopped up and served skewered by multiple cocktail sticks on a tiny little mound of coconut rice â€“ the sort of portion you might feed to a mouse in a cartoon. Stuffed peppers? Â£7!

A Â£28 seafood sharing platter for two might have fed two Lilliputians, but for two regular-sized adults it looked so tiny, we initially presumed it was for just one of us, and they were about to go back for the same again. What a hoot! One cute, litte spicy seafood parcel each. But how to divide the last of the three prawns? If they wanted to starve us, at least they could do so with evenly numbered bites. And, yes folks, thatâ€™s over Â£5 per morsel.

The chef came over earnestly to enquire what we thought. So we told him. The food is really enjoyable, spicey, carefully put together, but there just ainâ€™t enough of it. He nodded, said he might make some changes, and scuttled off looking a bit uncertain.

If you know whoâ€™s â€˜behindâ€™ a forthcoming restaurant, youâ€™re unlikely to go that far wrong as to what the end product is like. So if you know that a new brasserie is to be opened by Claudio Pulze (whose 50 previous establishments include everything from Aubergine and Zafferano) you expect something pretty useful. And all the more so when heâ€™s in league with Pierre Koffmann.

Koffmann may not be a household name nowadays, but â€“ if you take out the empire-building, self-promoting and foul-mouthed bits â€“ he was the Gordon Ramsay of the nineties. His Tante Claire restaurant â€“ on the site now the Ramsay HQ â€“ was invariably Londonâ€™s best. Then he moved TC to the Berkeley Hotel site which is now PÃ©trus, and didnâ€™t prosper. He dropped out of sight for a while, and his return has long been rumoured.

Amazingly, however, almost everything about the new restaurant manages to some extent to be wrong. It doesnâ€™t help that this is a site with poor proportions, and a bit of a chequered history to boot. (To make it all the more confusing, itâ€™s not so long ago that it was called PÃ©trus.) Itâ€™s been done over as a straight down-the-line Gallic brasserie which, without any patina of age, just looks a little bit cold and univiting.

The service was often pleasant, but it seemed to come and go rather. And couldnâ€™t the waiter have mentioned we were over-ordering? Our main dish came not only with the spuds and greens we had ordered, but also with some unadvertised rice and vegetables which, as it turned out, were included anyway. It added insult to injury when the unnecessary bowl of spinach came at Â£1 per teaspoonful.

So, Â£60 for a pretty basic lunch for one, with two glasses of wine and one cup of coffee. Regular readers will know weâ€™re big brasserie fans, but we canâ€™t say this is one weâ€™ll be rushing back to.

Service is decent but Ive marked it down because one of our dishes was forgotten and only delivered towards the end of our meal after a reminder was issued.  I certainly see the attraction but Im likely to explore other places in this price range before my next visit
We keep reading that this much-lauded Soho newcomer - fronted by Russell Norman, once a bigwig at the Caprice group - is some sort of Venetian snack bar (or, to impress you with our research,
). Has anyone looked at it? This is a New York restaurant, pure and simple. Or, more specifically, a Downtown restaurant.

The only wonder is that its taken so long for this particular style of deconstructed chic to make the jump from SoHo to Soho: Polpo immediately reminded us a of a particular SoHo-fringe operation, Peasant, which opened as long ago as 2000. Mr Norman readily admits such restaurants (if not that specific one) have provided just as much inspiration for him as anything in La Serenissima, and will even tell you the name of the particular firm of Big Apple architects whose work has inspired him: Avroko.

It isnt just the styling, of course (not generally commented on in the very positive early-days reviews elsewhere) which is responsible for the crush, but also the much-complimented food. Not that the cuisine is in any way astonishing, its just that it is generally very well done, and amazingly, well,

. The cicheti (Italian tapas) are very tasty, as well as remarkably economical. The highlight for us (lunching in the singular) was a delicious pile of green tapenade on a piece of toasted bread, but arancini (rice balls) also satisfied. To follow, fegato alla Veneziana, a small but very adequate dish for around Â£6, was well complemented by a plate of zucchini dressed with olive oil. Add a plate of roast autumn fruits (the best dish, dressed with a sprinkle of crumble), and youve still, with modest wine, had a very pleasant lunch for Â£25. Which may be another reason the place is already humming.

The obvious problem is that, with value like this, either prices will rise or tables will be impossible to get. Or both. So how long till the successor restaurant? As youve probably gathered, this is not the sort of place where a known reviewer is likely to be able to maintain any sort of anonymity, so we can tell you what Mr Norman told us - start looking out for number two some time next year.

In the heart of the grid sits this two-level outfit, which, somehow, doesnâ€™t seem quite real either. Why? Perhaps because itâ€™s trying to be a sort of beast you donâ€™t see very often â€“ a quality (read pricey) Indian restaurant, attached to a serious bar operation. Itâ€™s an act that might be easier to pull off in the West End, but, even there, we can think of only one place â€“ Mint Leaf â€“ which answers to that description.

There are various ways they try to square the, er, circle here. One is by having friendly service which- having allowed diners to enjoy a drink downstairs â€“ efficiently shepherds them to the restaurant above. Another is banning smoking throughout. Diners get to share some of the vibe of the bar operation, but no fug.

When you reach the elegant dining space, you find more friendly service â€“ mainly Russian, mainly female. The food is from a serious chef, Bhuwan Batt, who worked in top Indian hotels, before coming to London dinersâ€™ attention at Tabla, near Canary Wharf. The style of the dishes, and their presentation, is perhaps a bit more â€˜standardâ€™ than one might expect â€“ hotel experience coming through, perhaps â€“ but there are some unusual dishes, All those we tried â€˜workedâ€™, and they all came in generous quantities. (Puddings, however, are weak.)

Can this formula work in this location? As we left, mid-evening, the bar was busier than the restaurant, and we had no feeling that the barflies were going to end up dining above, so weâ€™d have our doubts. If we are wrong â€“ and this is a case where weâ€™d be pleased to be so â€“ Londonâ€™s dining-out scene is getting very mature indeed.

group is to continue its creep into the mid-market with the launch of a new Cecconiâ€™s restaurant in Shoreditch, East London.

To any restaurant which offers a dessert of Jerusalem artichoke cheesecake we say â€˜respectâ€™. With all due regard to Alain Ducasse and his somewhat bizarre recent boosterism of London as the restaurant capital of the world, the capitalâ€™s scene has been pretty dull of late.
? This repetition and re-invention of Anglo-French classics may be a worthy enough aim, but is that all there is to our restaurant scene? It does sometimes seem so at the moment.

and this â€œworld classâ€ sushi spot has, for a second year, scored the highest food-rating of any restaurant in the UK in our annual survey. So it seems that our reporters have long seen itâ€™s three-star potential, even if the tyre men did not.

Even if you think Michelin is an irrelevance, three stars is still a big deal mainly due to the rarity with which it is bestowed upon UK restaurants. The last time London saw three stars was in 2010 when Alain Ducasse at the Dorchester won the accolade. Before that you have to go back to 2004 when Hestonâ€™s Fat Duck got its third star. The Fat Duck, we get. But Alain Ducasse at the Dorchester? As our survey reporters say itâ€™s simply â€œnot in the same leagueâ€ and how it retains its three-star rating year-after-year is a mystery.

Other new stars awarded this week included Bibendum (now helmed by Claude Bosi) which received two stars, while the tyre men liberally sprinkled a further 16 one star accolades at venues across the UK (full list below). Perhaps the guide editors were feeling a bit nostalgic about Bibendumâ€™s home in Chelseaâ€™s iconic Michelin Building, because the reports we have had this year donâ€™t point towards a two-star performance. Itâ€™s good to see A Wong getting the recognition of a star from Michelin. However there are a couple of omissions that (we feel) continue to rankle. Gauthier Soho lost its star in 2012 and its continued absence from the list is baffling and starkly calls into question the judgement of the tyre men. And while weâ€™re on the subject, why was Chelseaâ€™s Medlar stripped of its star? Perhaps most confusing though is why Michelin continues to ignore Bethnal Greenâ€™s Typing Room? As one survey reporter says: â€œHow this place doesnâ€™t have a Michelin star is beyond belief!â€

Are you a â€˜Boboâ€™? Do you combine a bourgeois love of fine food with a bohemian contempt for tablecloths and all the other traditional appurtenances of catered quality dining? Congratulations. A restaurant precisely honed to your tastes has suddenly arrived â€“ far from its natural Hoxton or Shoreditch milieu â€“ in the very heart of Soho.

Indeed, short of being actually sited in a multi-story car park, itâ€™s difficult to imagine that a restaurant could be much more deconstructed than this one. This is not a natural setting, you might think, to enjoy a beautiful plump partridge, precisely cooked, accompanied perhaps by a tasty pumpkin mush with chestnuts and cream cheese. Or a decent chocolate mousse. Or to taste from the short but interesting range of wines, scrawled almost illegibly on a whiteboard. The aim here seems rather like that of Parisâ€™s much-fÃªted Chateaubriand â€“ to offer simple food of a quality which transcends the setting, to a degree which is perhaps supposed to be ironic.

That aim has substantially been achieved so, needless to say, the place has been a great hit with the foodie world â€“ on our visit, the the Terroirs boys were in, seeing what all the fuss was about. In the longer term, however, quite how such a profound lack of comfort will play with the wider market, itâ€™s really quite difficult to say.

Almost everything, it seems. First surprise is that â€“ far from the self-conscious streetiness and din of, say, MEATLiquor- this bright and tightly-packed corner spot has a rather old-fashioned style thatâ€™s something remarkably close to teashop-prim, especially by Soho standards.

On the Regentâ€™s Park fringe of Camden Town, Gordon Ramsayâ€™s glamorous conversion of a palatial boozer; food and service are good (rather than anything more), but the overall experience is highly suited to a celebration or romance.

Many people have been a bit mystified by this Gordon Ramsay group restaurant, bar and small hotel, in a converted pub on the outmost fringe of Camden Town. Whatâ€™s it for? Why would anyone want to go/stay there?

These are fair questions. Particularly on foot, itâ€™s not obviously on the route to or from anywhere, and â€“ even if much of the West End is within a 20-minute walk â€“ one can think of more obvious places to stay.

The key to it all, of course, is celebrity, which could in theory kick-start the virtuous circle â€“ crowds-buzz-more crowds â€“ to make the place a self-sustaining â€˜destinationâ€™. The trick, of course, is to make it  good enough to be more than a five-minute wonder.

The early signs, weâ€™d suggest. are that its standards are good enough. Indeed, in at least one respect, they are more than that â€“ this is a beautiful building, and it has been handsomely converted to create a very attractive ground-floor dining room (plus less interesting basement), and an unusually seductive bar area â€“ a combination ideal for a celebration or for romance.

The food and service play rather a supporting rÃ´le. Thatâ€™s not a particular criticism â€“ history suggests that it is a major challenge for spin-off celeb-chef-branded establishment even to achieve and maintain good/average standards, and that challenge is achieved impressively consistently here.

Admittedly, if you believed the Ramsay hype, and went expecting something special on the food front, you might be disappointed â€“ go in a party or romantic mood, though, and youâ€™ll probably have a very good time here.

North of Liverpool Street, an understated (to a fault) bar/restaurant offering the cuisine of Kyoto; despite the best efforts of the charming staff, and the beautiful presentation of the dishes, our early-days lunch was very dull.

We were rather excited by the idea of Chrysan â€“ the first non-Hakkasan-branded outlet of the group founded by Alan Yau (and from which he has now substantially sold out). Yau (currently launching the Bangkok-styled Naamyaa CafÃ© in Islington) has a knack of not offering just really good food, but an atmosphere thatâ€™s often characterised as â€˜sexyâ€™. He famously pulled off this trick at Hakkasan, and â€“ at a lower price point â€“ at Busaba Eathai too. This new establishment, surely,  would carry his spirit on, offering not just the refined cuisine of Kyoto, but also a good dose of slick style.

First impression on entering: unusually decorative staff, and they were trying very hard too. So far so good. Second impression: what happened to sexy? The bar is Japanese as if conceived by Scandinavians; it had no atmosphere at all when we swung by for a pre-lunch drink. Indeed, it was quite difficult to imagine how it ever could. Even for a business rendezvous, it seemed a cold and vacant space.

The long dining room was rather in keeping â€“ more elegant, but just as dull. Itâ€™s really not so hard for a restaurant to be understated in an upbeat way, as Lâ€™Anima convincingly demonstrates. Why did Hakkasan, with all its experience, not succeed in injecting some of the same pizzazz here?

Perhaps Kyoto is supposed to be dull? Japanese culture is much too impenetrable for any outsiders like us to pronounce on authoritatively, but we have been to Kyoto, and do not recall restaurants being totally unatmospheric. If anything, rather the reverse.

Someone must have decided that this was a venture which was all about the food. The Bento boxes were a key part of the menu, so two standard boxes and a veggie one seemed the way for our party of three to get a wide choice of the kitchenâ€™s output.

It turned out that each menu consisted of a bowl of miso soup (meaty, in the non-veggie option, which was not necessarily an advantage) plus two Perspex trays, each displaying  some of the prettiest food we have ever seen â€“ perhaps 20 highly-wrought mouth-sized bites.

Despite the efforts of the well-meaning staff, then, we couldnâ€™t really think of a single sort of lunch or dinner party â€“ Citified or otherwise â€“ for which this establishment could really be recommended in preference to, say, Lâ€™Anima.

The menu is mainly composed of straightforward food with a modest twist, but we started off with the simplest of dishes thatâ€™s all about sourcing, freshness and presentation â€“ the oysters passed those tests with flying colours. Two of us then eschewed the meatier main course options, preferring to share half a dozen small plates between us. And a very convivial lunch it was, even with just a modest glass of wine apiece. Nothing was trying too hard, everything was enjoyable, and some dishes â€“ such as scallops in filo pastry with harrissa mayo â€“ were really very good. Surprise highlight, though, was a notably light pear and almond tart.

We did wonder if prices might have seemed just a fraction high, as we spent just over Â£40 for twoâ€™ with all the food half price. All the more reason, then, to seek out the set lunch menu now available, which offers two of those small plates, plus a side, for just a tenner.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.
In a small and perhaps slightly subdued space, just off Carnaby Street, a corner barbecue specialist offering a small range of dishes of very high quality.

So much wanted to hate this new corner spot, just off Carnaby Street . Trendy menu (American barbecue), street food origins (under Hungerford Bridge, since you ask), bloggers delight What could there possibly be to like about it?

Almost everything, it seems. First surprise is that - far from the self-conscious streetiness and din of, say, MEATLiquor- this bright and tightly-packed corner spot has a rather old-fashioned style thats something remarkably close to teashop-prim, especially by Soho standards.

Third surprise? Well, how many proper restaurants actually offer food such that, the next day, you feel youd like to go back and eat it all again? Such was the status achieved by our pulled pork (which is one of the house speciality dishes). A changing range of interesting sides, such as marrow mash, is also included. The food all comes on white and blue enamel workmens tin dishes but, hey, nowheres perfect.

â€œItâ€™s an area under-served by good independent restaurants and I think people who live and work around there, as well as tourists, will welcome somewhere thatâ€™s offering something different.â€

But Barullo wonâ€™t be Garveyâ€™s only current venture â€“ his flagship Soho restaurant Rambla is reportedly as busy as ever. Garveyâ€™s paella-focused Bar Jaleo is still apparently in the pipeline, and is set to open later in 2019.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

The menu is mainly composed of straightforward food with a modest twist, but we started off with the simplest of dishes thats all about sourcing, freshness and presentation - the oysters passed those tests with flying colours. Two of us then eschewed the meatier main course options, preferring to share half a dozen small plates between us. And a very convivial lunch it was, even with just a modest glass of wine apiece. Nothing was trying too hard, everything was enjoyable, and some dishes - such as scallops in filo pastry with harrissa mayo - were really very good. Surprise highlight, though, was a notably light pear and almond tart.

We did wonder if prices might have seemed just a fraction high, as we spent just over Â£40 for two with all the food half price. All the more reason, then, to seek out the set lunch menu now available, which offers two of those small plates, plus a side, for just a tenner.

The hotel used to have the good-but-extremely-dull Chinese restaurant, The Dorchester Oriental, which closed last year. This is its replacement, but in a new site, in the basement, where the Dorchester Club - a sort of Annabels that never quite made it - used to be.

The Tang in the new venture comes from famed Hong Kong designer, David Tang (personally much in evidence on our visit). At the entrance, hes created a classic Art Deco cocktail bar, which makes a knockout initial impression. You then pass by a luxurious suite of private dining rooms. After all this build-up, the dining room itself is a big let-down. If the lighting had been better, perhaps it wouldnt have felt just one step up from Chinatown. It doesnt help that the seats and banquettes are not especially comfortable.

The lunchtime menu is mainly dim sum, of a quality varying from good to very good. Dishes by their nature are not large, but the prices (typically Â£4-Â£10) are such that you could have a light lunch here quite reasonably. Beware, though. When we asked for a couple of extra dishes, the waiter  - without asking if it was OK - raided the top end of the menu to bring us suckling pig (Â£16) and rather boring salt-baked chicken (Â£26). Including the 12.5% service, this puffed the bill up from around Â£130 for three (which would have been good value) to Â£180 (which wasnt).

Even dolled up for its new life as a restaurant (having recently been a club), this is still a plain space, with plain dÃ©cor and plain (and very â€™60s-looking) furniture. If this has been the original executive lounge after the construction of the building â€“ we know it wasnâ€™t, as the building famously remained vacant for many years â€“ one imagines that this is just how it might have felt. (Compare with Madison Avenue â€“ as recently depicted in â€˜Mad Menâ€™Â â€“ and you can see just how much more comfortable â€™60s office life must have been in New York than it was in London.)

Indeed, the place seems all the more practical as a business lunch venue because the lack of fuss that surround the whole operation is entirely in keeping with the dÃ©cor. The service is pleasant, and efficient enough, but devoid of pretensions, and the food is likewise.

In the late-â€™90s, mega-scale restaurants such as Mezzo and Quaglinoâ€™s were taken as proof that London was becoming the centre of the culinary world. But funnily enough, none of those spaces ever made you want to say â€˜wowâ€™.

â€˜Wow!â€™ is a word that easily springs to mind as you enter this vast newcomer, in the offbeat location of Camden Market. You donâ€™t need to have read the press release about the 500 covers, the 10,000-strong Indian design team, or the longest bar in the world (hand-carved from Lapis stone) to realise that someone has just dropped shed-loads of cash creating this place.

Huge wood carvings span from floor to ceiling. Down one side, a glass curtain-wall looks â€“ bizarrely â€“ onto a heavy good line (with the odd passing freight train for added amusement). Do we sound impressed? We were! And also by the affable service. Inevitably, though, the sensation is of eating in a huge venue or nightclub rather than a restaurant â€“ something the huge bar and prominent DJ did nothing to dispel.

How could the pan-Asian food live up? And especially at prices, which certainly donâ€™t aim to attract passing Goths, punks or whatever Camden trendies call themselves nowadays. The initial crowd looked more staid than you might expect for such a scene, presumably having heard that Ian Pengelley (ex E&O and the doomed Pengelleys) was at the stoves.

All our dishes were beautifully presented, and the sushi and sashimi in particular passed muster. Overall though, awareness of the hefty prices stifled some of the enjoyment, as did a middle-of-the-road quality in many dishes. Puddings were extremely boring.

All that said, the place delivers a very different Big Night Out. So weâ€™ve awarded this brave but batty venture four stars. Can it succeed? Well thatâ€™s the $64,000 â€“ no, if the rumours are true make that the Â£12 million â€“ question.

For 28 years weve been curating reviews of the UKs most notable restaurant. This year diners have submitted over 50,000 reviews to create the most authoritative restaurant guide in the UK.

Once youre there, this canalside development is, in an Americanised kind of way, surprisingly attractive  given that its dominated by a flyover (the Westway). It helps that the landlords - no doubt with lavish incentives - have attracted a critical mass of restaurants, including an already-popular Japanese (Yakitoria), an airy gastropub (The Union), a soon-to-open fish specialist, and the Chinese restaurant we review today.

The food, though, is a redeeming feature. Dim sum are a speciality (served lunch and dinner), and come at a prices reminiscent of Chinatown, and up to the same standards as the best operators there. Larger dishes - such as Peking Duck and steamed sea bass - were also realised to a superior standard. Puddings included an oddly satisfying, blue blancmange-y number. In fact, everything was consistently above par.
So, when youre next passing (just kidding) give the place a try. Or, if youre a real fan of Chinese cooking, you might even find it positively worth seeking out.

The idea sounds so attractive. A bistro named after its ever-changing wine selection: ten whites and ten reds, all bought in (at most) ten case parcels. Offer straightforward food to go with it, and serve it in a cramped and decidedly no-nonsense setting handy for, say, the Royal Opera House. Et voilÃƒÂ !
Rather similarly, the list of still wines seemed disappointingly straightforward for a place that plays on its wine appeal. But the main impression was how expensive the wines were by the glass.

Surely the joy of a place like this is to sample? Yet 1/6-bottle glasses of wine are generally priced somewhere round one third the price of a full bottle. Why a premium approaching 100% for samplers? And if youâ€™re going to offer just one dessert wine, should it be a Sauternes at Â£10 a glass?

Bread was pretty horrible. Hardly surprising: baguettes in London are almost always like cotton wool. But this isnâ€™t a French restaurant. Why not give people the best local-style bread? Or, in London, pain rustique is invariably a better choice. The coffee was unremarkable too.

to announce the top 5Â trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London.Â Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on whatÂ people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets perÂ week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

On a Kensington site thatâ€™s had a somewhat chequered history of late, a smart but somewhat subdued bistro offering food English dishes of very high quality, under the auspices of Square chef Philip Howard.

Philip Howard is one of those blameless chefs who beavers away doing what chefs are supposed to do â€“ for younger readers, thatâ€™s cooking â€“ year after year. Itâ€™s no particular surprise, then, that standards at his grand Mayfair restaurant, the Square, are a model of consistency. His has proved to be a nothing-to-scare-the-horses cuisine that has long made this one of the top destinations for grander business dining.

Part of the problem is that these are premises which just donâ€™t have zing. Though they are in a street long associated with restaurants (and one that leads into one of the most chichi Kensington backwaters), Abingdon Road has always struck us as rather a forlorn thoroughfare, and the recent establishments on this site have never managed to transcend their location.

Perhaps, though, the cooking here will make it â€˜third time luckyâ€™ for Ms M. Itâ€™s certainly of a very high quality (and itâ€™s already driving the foodie end of the Twitterati to heights of ecstasy). On our meal the bread was splendid (weâ€™d suggest the sourdough), and an autumnal soup was as rich and as satisfying as you could hope for, and came â€“ rather unusually â€“ with a mini-kebab or two. We canâ€™t remember precisely what they consisted of, but they certainly added interest! A duck leg from the set lunch menu was precisely cooked, the meat falling from the bone but not at all overcooked. A small but perfectly-formed pear financier (sponge pudding, not a chap who tears up Â£50 notes) was clearly the work of a master.

A guest was equally happy with his meal. His elegantly-plated ox-tongue â€“ surely an oxmoron? â€“ certainly looked like the sort of dish youâ€™d fine in a much fancier sort of joint, and he expressed delight both with it and the rabbit terrine which preceded it. Coffee and chocolates were also excellent. Both the menu and the wine list are extensive and reasonably priced (and the latter offers a good choice by the 25cl carafe).

One very much senses here the inspiration of Arbutus, a seminal West End success of recent times. Kensington, however, is emphatically not Soho: only if the food here succeeds in attracting a dedicated â€“ and hopefully animated â€“ following does there seem any real hope of a breakthrough on the atmosphere front.

For restaurant critics, offbeat formulas make for easy copy. Reviewing this ambitious-looking new Clerkenwell venture â€“ which prominently advertises its â€˜Thai-Indian cuisineâ€™Â â€“ therefore looked set to be a cinch.

My old friend obligingly set about ordering a Thai set lunch to complement my Indian one. I began to congratulate myself on how easily the column was to be filled up with descriptions of the varying national styles of dishes (interspersed with the occasional insightful point of comparison between the two).

What remained was a far cry from the quirky culinary experience with which I had hoped to regale you. The service was fine, if not especially engaging, but looked as if it might get rather over-stretched as the place filled up.

So is there any postive reason at all seek this restaurant out? Mercifully, it does turn out that there is at least one: an unusually light and grand function room (for 25), which would make a pleasant and good-value venue for private dining. But any culinary adventure is very definitely off the menu.

(Hey, one in Spanish dress, one Japanese â€“ at least theyâ€™d be noticed.) If you do summon up the courage to go in, the Stygian ground floor lobby feels positively spooky. The whole approach is so wrong that it makes you wonder how anyone â€“ even more a highly regarded international operator with a number of outlets in the East â€“ can spend millions, and still not have thought properly about the basics of getting people into such an obscurely-located restaurant in the first place. Weâ€™re told that measures are in hand to put right many of the most obvious defects. But is there time? Without the mother of all relaunches, this place is fast beginning to look like the biggest pre-Christmas turkey London has ever seen.

to announce the top 5 trending restaurants on Twitter each week in London. Twizoo is an app that gives restaurant recommendations based on what people are saying on Twitter, and analyses over 50,000 incoming tweets per week to determine which restaurants are attracting the most buzz.

Youâ€™ve probably noticed on Twitter on the left hand side of your â€˜Homeâ€™ page thereâ€™s a â€˜Trendsâ€™ list. Twizoo has built the same thing, but solely for London restaurants. Our number crunching detects the rate of change of influential mentions on Twitter. For example, â€˜Christmasâ€™ is currently trending on Twitter, which means thereâ€™s been a spike of mentioning Christmas now compared with the rest of the year.

Applying this to Twizooâ€™s algorithms: if X restaurant usually gets on average 10 tweets per week, but this week it gets 32 tweetsâ€¦ thatâ€™s a pretty big change, so itâ€™s a good indicator something notable is going on. The algorithm notes restaurants that have the highest rate of change and ranks them based on which placesâ€™ tweets are the most positive collectively and then it takes the top of those based on how influential the individuals are who tweeted. Simple see?

Some say plans to gentrify the infamous Walkers Court would have the â€˜King of Sohoâ€™ turning in his grave; home, as it was, to his Raymond Revuebar. But others, like Soho Estates and the developers behind the Â£45m project, say they have no wish to sanitise the area, butÂ simply want to increase footfall to its legal businesses.

Indeed, it seems that The Box (a burlesque bar favoured by louche young Royals and movie stars) will remain in situ, in place of Paul Raymondâ€™s Revuebar (although a neon sign will be installed in tribute to the late tycoonâ€™s eponymous venue). And, fittingly, the man who could possibly lay claim to Raymondâ€™s title as â€˜King of Sohoâ€™, Russell Norman, has plans to open a restaurant in the Walkers Court development.

Yes, the sleaze is slowly being wiped away by the bistros, coffee shops and high-end clothing stores, but Soho retains enough of its past identity to remain an edgier central London location than most.

Further proof that Sohoâ€™s seedy roots are being eradicated? An illegal strip club on Great Windmill Street was closed down this summer and will be repurposed as a 50-cover restaurant and Folk clothing shop. New owner Gordon Kerr may be a first time restaurateur, but heâ€™s getting some first rate support in the form of Hawksmoor duo, Huw Gott and Will Beckett, who are advising on this new British meat concept.

We know that Russell Norman has agreed a deal on a 5,000 sq ft premises in Walkers Court but the â€˜Restaurant Manâ€™ is yet to announce firm plans for his as yet unnamed new venture. A pizza joint has been rumoured.
A Soho restaurant that only takes reservations? Thatâ€™s what this thoroughly British dining concept coming to Wardour Street is proposing; surely it will never catch on!

â€“ the restaurant bloggers apparently proclaim â€œJerusalemâ€™s coolestâ€ came to Soho this spring and the critics cannot stop raving about it. On our visit we found a characterful little spot serving refreshing, modern cuisine.

â€œTruly heavenlyâ€ tapas and an â€œexcellent wine listâ€ fuel the â€œbusy buzzâ€ of this stylish haunt, a sibling to Salt Yard, just off Carnaby Street; â€œdespite its initial pokey appearanceâ€, itâ€™s â€œa lovely place to spend a long afternoonâ€.
